DASAKUMARA CHARITA

DR. B√úHLER’S
CRITICAL PREFACE
TO
PART I
(First Edition.)
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

THE present edition of the P√ªrvap√Æ·π≠hik√¢ has for its basis a Ms. marked N., which is about 100 years old, and was lent to the editor by Govind Sh√¢str√Æ Nirantar, of Nasik. A careful collation of Wilson’s B. Ms., called in the notes B^(w)., and of a fragment of his A. Ms., designated A^(w)., has been made. Bw. has been written by a Mar√¢·π≠h√¢ scribe, and is probably 250 years old. It is preserved in the Library of the India Office and numbered 107.

A^(w)., which consists of six leaves (fols. 27, 30-34), is a modern transcript, made probably for Professor Wilson’s use. The six leaves were found in a copy of Wilson’s printed edition of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita, belonging to the India Office Library.

The sources from which the text of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita has been taken are:

A. Mss.

  1. S., a Ms. of the 16th century, lent by Bh√¢u ≈ö√¢str√Æ, of S√¢t√¢r√¢ in the Dekhan.
  2. G., a Ms., about 250 years old, bought in Surat for the Government of Bombay, Deccan College, Coll. of 1871-72, Nro. 49.
  3. A^(r)., an incomplete Ms., about 150 years old, lent by a ≈ö√¢str√Æ of Ankleshwar, near Broach.

B. COMMENTARIES

  1. Pa^(d)., a modern transcript of a good copy of Kav√Ændra Sarasvat√Æ’s Padachandrik√¢, a very full and prolix, but sometimes injudicious commentary, Elphinstone College, Coll. of 1867-68, III., Nro. 1.
  2. Bh√ª., a modern, very correct copy of ≈öivar√¢ma’s Bh√ªsha·πáa, Elphinstone College, Coll. of 1867-68, III., Nro. 4.
  3. Ah^(d)., a very incorrect Ms. of the S√¢r√¢m≈õa·π≠√Æk√¢, attributed in the colophons to the cantos to Da·πá·∏çin, Deccan College, Coll. of 1872-73, Nro. 18.

C. EDITIONS.

  1. W., Professor H. H. Wilson’s editio princeps.
  2. C., the Calcutta edition of Sa·πÉvat 1906.

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

DR. B√úHLER’S
PREFACE
TO
PART I
(Second Edition.)

For the second edition, the Da≈õakum√¢racharita of Da·πá·∏çin, with the commentaries of Kav√Ændra Sarasvat√Æ and ≈öivar√¢ma, by Messrs. Go·∏çbole and Parab, has been compared, as well as Professor T√¢r√¢n√¢th Tarkav√¢chaspati’s annotated edition of 1872, which could be used only for the notes of the first edition.

DR. PETERSON’S
PREFACE
TO
PART II
(First Edition.)
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

THIS edition of Books IV. to VIII. of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita has been prepared, with Dr. B√ºhler’s concurrence, to complete the edition of the work in the Bombay Sanskrit Series. Three manuscripts have been used, A, a manuscript in the Bhao Daji Collection of the Bombay Branch of the Royal Asiatic Society, written in ≈öaka 1687, B and C, two manuscripts in the Bombay Government Collection, dated respectively Samvat 1851 and Samvat 1880. Wilson’s (W) and Godbole and Parab’s (G) editions have also been used, and the former has been collated throughout.

Little is known of the author of the book, Da·πá·∏çin. His date has still to be settled. Wilson placed him in the eleventh century : more recent writers would assign him to the sixth. The older view will, I think, eventually be found to be nearer the truth. At all events, I believe, it can be shown that Da·πá·∏çin is a later writer than V√¢mana, who belongs to the eighth century.

Pischel, who believes that Da·πá·∏çin is older than V√¢mana, but admits that this cannot be proved by a comparison of the one writer’s K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa with the other’s K√¢vy√¢la·πÉk√¢rav·πõitti, tells us that Kielhorn had pointed out to him that inK√¢vy√¢dar≈õa,II. 51,

‡§® ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡•á ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•á ‡§® ‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ‡•§
‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ó‡•ã ‡§® ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Da·πá·∏çin would appear to be criticising part of V√¢mana’s rule, K√¢vy√¢la·πÉk√¢rav·πõitti iv. 2, 8, ‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§æ‡§É. It might be conceded to Pischel, that these passages in the two books, if they stood alone, would not necessarily do more than disclose a difference of opinion between Da·πá·∏çin and V√¢mana, on matter of common controversy, without being conclusive as to their relative age. But the passages in question do not stand alone. AtK√¢vy√¢dar≈õa II. 358, 359.

‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡•Å‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§µ ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡•å‡•§
‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§µ ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡••
‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶ ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö‡•§

I see a clear reference to V√¢mana’s teaching with regard to the figures of speech which he calls ananvaya, sa·πÉdeha, upam√¢r√ªpakam and utpreksh√¢vayava. For V√¢mana these are four separate ala·πÉkƒÅras requiring separate treatment. Da·πá·∏çin has made the first three fall under his general definition of upam√¢ and r√ªpakam respectively. But he deems it necessary to note that he has done so. The fourth, says, is a mere variety of utpreksh√¢. He mentions it at all, it is clear, only out of respect for some predecessor. In the present state of our knowledge we must, I submit, take it that that predecessor is V√¢mana, and that the ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§Éof K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa II. 359 is a challenge of V√¢mana’s dictum K√¢vy√¢la·πÉk√¢rav·πõitti IV. 3, 33, ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§É.

Da·πá·∏çin’s contraction of the styles of poetry to two only, the Vaidarbha and the Gau·∏ça varieties, appears also to me to be a reflection on V√¢mana, who recognizes three, the Vaidarbha, Gau·∏ça and P√¢√±ch√¢la (K√¢vy√¢d. I. 40-43, K√¢vy√¢l. I. 2, 9-13).*

We know from R√¢ja≈õekhara’s verse, ≈ö√¢r·πÖgadharapaddhati 174

‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡••

that Da·πá·∏çin was celebrated as the author of three books. Two are our book and the K√¢vy√¢dar’sa. The third is still to seek. Pischel, who believes that it is the M·πõichchhaka·π≠ik√¢, has to deal with an important passage in the beginning of the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa, in which Da·πá·∏çin apparently refers to a work on metre by himself called the Chhandovichiti. Da·πá·∏çin’s Chhandovichiti, has not come down to us, or has not yet been recovered, and it is evident that there is a prim√¢ facie possibility that it may be

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

*Pandit Mahe≈õchandra Ny√¢yaratna, in his interesting paper in the Proceedings of the Bengal Asiatic Society for 1887, p.193, holds that it is unquestionable that V√¢mana is by much the older of the two writers. He does not, however, give his reasons. The Pandit has been before me with the observation that K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa II. 197,

‡§Ö‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§ï‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•å‡§µ‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§Æ‡§É‡••

is a reminiscence of B√¢·πáa in K√¢dambari, Bombay Edition, p.102, 1. 16. ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§®‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§™‡§®‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ó‡§π‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•å‡§µ‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç. The remarks which follow onthe limpatƒ´va verse were written before I knew of the Pandit’s paper, where the same view is taken.

PETERSON’S PREFACE

R√¢ja≈õekhara’s third book, leaving no room for the M·πõichchhakatik√¢. Jacobi has taken this view (Indische Studien, XVII. p. 44). Pischel is disposed to think that in the passage in the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa Da·πá·∏çinis not referring to a book at all.

I cannot think that he is right here. In K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa I. 2. Da·πá·∏çintells us that his book is to be a compendium of previous works on K√¢vya based on a wide study of existing poems. In v. 10 he says that his authorities divide k√¢vyainto two parts, body and soul. By the body of poetry is meant a row of words characterized by meaning of a choice kind. This leads him (v. 11) to the division of the body or material substance of k√¢vyainto what we call prose (gadyam) and poetry (padyam), and into the sub-division of this latter according as it is measured by syllables or by quantity. He then goes on (v. 11):

‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡•å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ç‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

“The full exposition of that subject (sc. padyam) has been given in the Chhandovichiti:that science is a ship for those who wish to cross the ocean of poetry.” Accordingly, in the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa Da·πá·∏çinsays no more about the laws of metre. If I have interpreted the context rightly, it seems clear that Da·πá·∏çin is referring to a book here, as also that he can only be referring to a book of his own composition. For nothing but the fact that he was able to refer to a book of his own could account for Da·πá·∏çin’s

omitting from his compendium one half of his subject, as that has just been defined by himself.
But while I think it probable that Da·πá·∏çin wrote a Chhandovichiti, as V√¢mana had done before him, I cannot hold, with any certainty, with Jacobi that we are to recognize in it the third pillar of his fame. In addition to the reference in the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa to the Chhandovichiti as a book Da·πá·∏çin had written, there is an equally clear reference to a work to be called the Kal√¢parichchheda, which Da·πá·∏çin intended to write, K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa III. 171.

‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§É‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡•á ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡••

If it should turn out that Da·πá·∏çindid not live to write the Kal√¢parichheda, Jacobi’s hypothesis would recover great additional probability. But as matters stand it seems more likely that the Chhandovichiti and the Kal√¢parichchheda were regarded by Da·πá·∏çinand his admirers as mere appendages to his K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa, and that neither the one nor the other of them can be the third book, on which, alongside of the K√¢vy√¢dar≈öa and the Da≈õakum√¢racharita, his fame rested. It is still, therefore, necessary to examine Pischel’s plea in favour of the M·πõichchhaka·π≠ik√¢. It can be shown that his argument will not bear a careful examination of the passages in the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa on which it is founded. Da·πá·∏çinrefers twice to the verse, occurring in the M·πõichchhaka·π≠ik√¢, ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•Ä‡§µ ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡§ø &c. If the second reference stood alone, and if the verse had not been identified, we might have been unable to say whether it was original or not. For Da·πá·∏çin gives it there, without note or comment, as an instance of a stanza containing two or more figures of speech which are co-ordinate with each other, not subordinate, the one to the other. But he is able to do this only because he has already (II, 226 ff.) referred to, and been at great pains to refute, the opinion of previous writers, that the verse in question consists of upam√¢s only, and not, as Da·πá·∏çin holds, of two utpreksh√¢s and one upam√¢. The passage need not be given at length here. I will only note that Da·πá·∏çin first gives the two examples ( ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø and ‡§Ö‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø) required by his two-fold division of utpreksh√¢. He then goes on :

‡§≤‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•Ä‡§µ ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•Ä‡§µ‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Ç ‡§®‡§≠‡§É‡•§‡§á‡§§‡•Ä‡§¶‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

This can only mean

“That (well-known) verse too ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•Ä‡§µ ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡§ø is mostly* composed of utpreksh√¢s.”

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

* ‡§≠‡•Å‡§Ø‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç. Da·πá·∏çinis referring to the fact that the verse has two utpreksh√¢s as against one upam√¢. Pischel’s translation “in a high degree” and B√∂htlingk’s “durchaus” both seem to miss this point.

B√∂htlingk takes the view I am urging against Pischel. But his argument that Da·πá·∏çin would hardly have ascribed here a verse of his own to ‚Äúa (certain) poet,‚Äù vv. 223, 225, and even to “a(certain) man"rests on a misconception of the terms so translated, ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ and ‡§™‡•Å‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ. They have nothing to do with an ascription of authorship, a sense in which the latter of the two would be unique. In the figure utpreksh√¢ some one must, by a quaint conceit, represent something as entirely different from what it really is. ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ “the (not a) poet,” and ‡§™‡•Å‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ"the man,” i. e. the speaker.Da·πá·∏çin introduces the expressions to drive home the fact that in such verges ‡§á‡§µis exactly equal to ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á and the like.

The occurrence in the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa of a verse which is taken from the M·πõichchhaka·π≠ik√¢ is not, it should be observed in passing, without a significance of its own. It does not prove that Da·πá·∏çinwas the author of the play, on the contrary. But it does go to prove that Da·πá·∏çin, who quotes the play, cannot be a very old writer. For the M·πõichchhaka·π≠ik√¢ belongs to period when people had begun to forget how to write good Sanskrit.

Dr. B√ºhler pointed out to me that Mr. Lewis Rice has, Inscriptions from ≈örava·πáa Belgola, p. 43, brought to light an important passage in which a verse from “Da·πá·∏çin” in praise of a Jain writer ≈ör√Ævarddhadeva, author of a Ch≈´·∏çƒÅma·πái, is quoted in an inscription which dates from the ≈öaka year 1050=1128 A. D.

** ‡§Ø ‡§è‡§µ ‡§â‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§®‡§æ**

‡§ú‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§É‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ü‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§¨‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•á ‡§ú‡§ø‡§π‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

Mr. Rice would use this to help to settle ≈ör√Ævarddha’s date, and that of various other authors and works that are in the inscription put before his time.“Da·πá·∏çinis placed by the best authorities in the 6th century A. D. It follows that ≈ör√Ævarddha lived either at or before that period, and that the various authors mentioned above must be understood to have preceded him.” It will be evident from what has been already written that these conclusions cannot stand. There is not a shred of evidence to show that Da·πá·∏çinlived in the sixth century. On the contrary it is absolutely certain that he follows B√¢·πáa, who belongs to the early part of the seventh century; and it is, as I trust, I have shown, very probable that he is later than V√¢mana, who belongs to the eighth. If the “Da·πá·∏çin” of this inscription is our Da·πá·∏çin, we are as likely in the end to get at his date through ≈ör√Ævarddha’s as to be able to determine ≈ör√Ævarddha’s from his. But I have to close thesetentative remarks with the warning that the Da·πá·∏çin. of this inscription is probably not our author, but another writer of his name, who must be distinguished from him. I mean the author of the Mallik√¢m√¢ruta, a play written in rivalry of Bhavabh√ªti’s M√¢lat√Æm√¢dhava, which has been printed in Calcutta, and copies of which are in the India Office Library and British Museum. Burnell has wrongly given the name of the author of that book as Ra·πÖgan√¢tha. That was his father’s name, and the line goes up through ≈ör√Æk·πõish·πáa to Gokulan√¢tha. They belonged to the Tu·πá·∏ç√Æra country, a district near Conjeevaram. All these names, taken from the preface of the Mallik√¢m√¢ruta, are against the idea that we are dealing here with the author of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita; and the style of the book in no way approaches that of our author. We must therefore hold that there were two Da·πá·∏çins, and it seems likely that the ≈örava·πáa Belgola inscription refers to the younger and less famous one.

P. PETERSON.

ELPHINSTONE COLLEGE,
BOMBAY, 1st July, 1891.

PREFACE TO THE SECOND EDITION
(Parts I and II together.)

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1722596457Screenshot2024-07-30115049.png"/>

The present is a revised edition in one volume ofDa·πá·∏çin’s Da≈öakum√¢racharita. Part I, includingthe P√∫rvap√Æ·π≠hik√¢ and the first three Uchchhv√¢sas of the work proper was edited as No. X of the Bombay Sanskrit Series by the late Dr. G. B√ºhler, C.I. E., as far back as 1887; Part II, No. XLII including the remaining five Uchchhv√¢sas was issued by the late Dr.P. Peterson. M.A., in 1891. Since the text of both parts together does not make more than 145 pages, the present edition is issued in a single volume.

Considerable additions have been made to the notes, and the text has been collated with the more recent editions of the Nir·πáayas√¢gara Press and also a South-Indian recension. The latter contains in several places better readings, which have been adopted.

In preparing this edition, I am much indebted to Pandit R. V. Krishnam√¢ch√¢rya, Mr. Ramanuja Iyangar, Pandit K. R. Chakravarti and Rao Saheb T. A. Gopinath Rao, M. A., for many valuable suggestions. My acknowledgments are also due to D. R. Bhandarkar, Esquire, M. A., Dr. S. K. Belvalkar and Dr. N. G. Sardesai, Manager, Oriental Books Supplying Agency, Poona,for their kindness in lending me such books as I required from time to time.

  **POONA.      ** **}               
    G. J. AGASHE.

31st December, 1917.**

INTRODUCTION

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1722596747Screenshot2024-07-30115049.png"/>

Popularity of the work.

Paucity of Proseworks.

We propose in the sequel to make an attempt to assess the literary ** **merit of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita. It will suffice here to state that as a sample of prose composition it has enjoyed a unique popularity. It is difficult to account for this marked favour except onthe ground of the paucity of prose works in Sanskrit.

2.B√¢·πáa’s ‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ and ‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§∞‡•Ä and Subandhu’s ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ are well-known, but are rather much too hard for beginners.

Dhanap√¢la’s ‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡§Æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡•Ä, V√¢d√Æbhasi·πÉha’s‡§ó‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø and Abhinava-Bha·π≠·π≠a B√¢·πáa’s ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç,a though said to be extant, have not yet found a publisher. ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§∞‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç, ‡§§‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä and ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•Ä are known only by name, but have not yet been discovered.

Easy style of thework.

  1. Under these circumstances, the Da≈õakum√¢racharita has been found handy for beginners at a stage intervening between thePa√±chatantra or Hitopade≈õa on the one hand, and advanced prose works like the Harshacharita and K√¢dambar√Æ on the other. This alone can account for the work being prescribed by the Universities of Calcutta and Bombay,and for the issue of selections by the former and the publication of the complete work by the Bombay Educational Department. But this is only one of the reasons of the popularity of the work.

Degeneracy of taste.

  1. Appayya D√Ækshita, the famous authorof the Kuvalay√¢nanda beguiled his leisure hours by writing an abridgment of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita and one Gopin√¢tha, referred to later on, showed the same partiality to the work about the same time. Very recent times have also found an admirer of this Da·πá·∏çinin Kavimalla bha·π≠·π≠aHarimalla of Jeypore, who in 1894 published, among other works, his abridgment of the P√∫rvap√Æ·π≠hik√¢ ( ‡§¶‡§∂‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ ) in a small brochure entitled ‚ÄúJayapura-Pancharangam." It is possible that the very questionable taste with which Da·πá·∏çin has dwelt on love scenes, the effrontery and nonchalance with which intrigues in the harem are avowed by the lovers and the utter callousness with which the advances of these princely suitors are encouraged by the ladies of the harem, all these apparently caught on the imagination of these latter-day Pandits and induced them to raise the author to the position of “a prince of poets‚Äù !Unless we are prepared to own a degeneracy of taste in recent times, it is hard to justify the estimation in which the work seems to have been held.

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

INTRODUCTION

THE P√õRVAP√é·π¨HIK√Ñ

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî** **

Da·πá·∏çin’sown workincomplete.

  1. Da·πá·∏çin’s own work, as now extant, has neither a beginning nor an end.The first is supplied by a P√ªrvap√Æ·π≠hik√¢ or Introductionwhich is believed on very good grounds to be the work of some other hand, and the last by a supplement called ‚Äú ≈öesha” which is known to be the work of a Deccan Pandit by name Chakrap√¢·πái D√Ækshita. There is something suspicious even about the title of the work, since Da·πá·∏çin’sText gives only eight stories and not ten, the remaining two being supplied by the P√ªrvap√Æ·π≠hik√¢

Bha·π≠·π≠a NƒÅrƒÅya·πáƒÅ’sP√ªrvap√Æ·π≠hik√¢.

  1. The Deccan College Manuscript Library contains another P√ªrvap√Æ·π≠hik√¢, No.32, Coll. 1873-74. This is much more concise andconsistent withthe narrative in the text of Da·πá·∏çin’sown work and is now for the first time published as an Appendix to this edition. This P√ªrvap√Æ·π≠hik√¢ following colophon:‚Äî

‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§∞‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§§‡•ç‡••

The first point worth noticing in this colophon is the position of the absolutive ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø,which can be construed either way, that is, either with‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç or with the following expression ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§∞‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç. If ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø be taken with ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç, it would raise the presumption of this P√ªrvap√Æ·π≠hik√¢ having been written by Da·πá·∏çinhimself. But if a P√ªrvap√Æ·π≠hik√¢ was written by the author himself, the question naturally arises ‚Äúwhy should Bha·π≠·π≠a N√¢r√¢ya·πáa have attempted another?‚Äù B√¢·πáa’s son completing his father’s unfinished work is intelligible enough, but why should a stranger seek to fill up a gap left by another author ? Professor Wilson ventures the conjecture that it ‚Äú may be regarded as the work of one of the author’s disciples," though be observes at the same time that‚Äú its general congruity with the acknowledged composition of Da·πá·∏çinrenders it not improbably his work." (p. 5, Introduction).

P√ªrvap√Æ»õhik√¢ the work of some other hand.

  1. Even a cursory examination of the P√ªrvap√Æ·π≠hik√¢ is, however, sufficient to show that it is not the work of the author of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita. Professor Wilson himself admits that ‚Äúit is less ambitiously written" and adds that ‚Äúas the incidents related are in one or two cases, briefly repeated in the body of the work and with some contradictions, doubts have been started as to the accuracy of the attribution.‚Äù (p. 5 Intro.) Further on at p. 22, in noticing √† contradiction between an incident as related in the P√ªrvap√Æ»õhik√¢ and in the body of the main work, Professor Wilson remarks that ‚Äúeither the author has been nodding or the Introduction is the work of a different writer who has been heedless or forgetful of the narrative of his predecessor."

The style inferior.

  1. Professor Wilson has dismissed the subject of the inferiority of the P√ªrvap√Æ·π≠hik√¢ with the single remark thatit is ‚Äú less ambitiously written.‚ÄùBut¬¥as a matter of fact, it lacks not only the grace and finish, but contains comparatively more unfelicitous and unmeaning compounds and greater transgressions of grammar and idiom than are to be found in the main work. There is, besides, an unevenness in style as between one Uchchhv√¢sa and another, the fifth reaching a high level of elegance and the first being the most crude—a circumstance which raises a suspicion of even this part of the work having proceeded from different hands.

Contradictions and repetitions.

  1. The doubt about the identity of the authorship of these two parts of the work is confirmed by the repetitions and contradictions which disfigure the P√¢rvap√Æ·π≠hik√¢. The description of the personal charms of Vasumat√Æ on p. 2 and that of Avantisundar√Æ on pp. 25 and 26 of the P√ªrvap√Æ»õhik√¢ are evidently faint copies of the word-picture of Kalpa-Sundar√Æ (p. 74 of the text) in the story of Upah√¢ravarm√¢.

Omissions.

  1. Besides the contradictions noted by Wilson (at p. 22 of his Introduction), we may note that there are omissions also which cause a deal of confusion. In para. 1 (p. 67. 11. 1-2), the daughter of Upah√¢ravarm√¢’s nurse speaks of certain overtures made to her by a forester (‡§∂‡§¨‡§∞) and of her escape from that plight through the good offices of a follower of the King of Mithil√¢, an incident of which there is no trace in the P√ªrvap√Æ·π≠hik√¢.

Bha·π≠·π≠aN√¢r√¢ya·πáa’s P√ªrvap√Æthik√¢is more concise and consistent.

  1. As stated above, the P√ªrvap√Æ·π≠hik√¢ printed in the Appendix is (1) more concise and (2) more consistent withDa·πá·∏çin’s text, both in the order of narration and the nature of incident. The princes introduced to the reader in Bha·π≠·π≠a N√¢r√¢ya·πá√¢’s work follow each other in the order of Da·πá·∏çin’s text, whereas the accepted P√ªrvap√Æ·π≠hik√¢ opens with the story of Upah√¢ravarm√¢ in the place of Apah√¢ravarm√¢ of the text. Bha·π≠·π≠a N√¢r√¢ya·πáa’s Introduction begins with an account of Somasarm√¢, but the P√ªrvap√Æ·π≠hik√¢ ends with an account of the prince who bore the name of Somadatta.

Bha·π≠·π≠a N√¢r√¢ya·πáa gives in a few words the same story which is presented in greater detail in the P√ªrvap√Æ·π≠hik√¢, which has been commonly accepted as the composition of Da·πá·∏çin himself, but which would seem at best to have merely obtained his approval. If the two now brought together were carefully compared, it would appear as if some of the disciples of Da·πá·∏çin, as hinted by Professor Wilson, filled in a sketch approved by the author and each one tried his hand according to his own fancy and literary ability, and it is possible that the longest and the one which in any degree made an approach in manner and diction to the composition of the Guru was finally accepted.

Discrepancies.

  1. Without some such surmise, it is hard to account for the many discrepancies in detail which a comparison of the two cannot fail to disclose. For instance, we find in Bha·π≠·π≠a N√¢r√¢ya·πáa’s work Mati≈õarm√¢ for Sitavarm√¢ among the King’s ministers. So also we find Dharmap√¢la having only two sons assigned to him, viz., K√¢map√¢la and Sumitra; and Padmodbhava having three instead of two, Sumantra being transferred from Dharmap√¢la’s line of descent. Again, the third minister Mati≈õarm√¢ has only two sons instead of three.

As the story proceeds, we have more minor differences in detail, such as the gift by ≈öiva of a spear (≈õula) instead of a mace (gad√¢). In the story of Somadatta, Bha·π≠·π≠a N√¢r√¢ya·πáa speaks of the Brahmin (who presented the foundling) as wandering in the Da·πá·∏çak√¢ forest instead of on the bank of the K√¢ver√Æ, hundreds of miles away in the South. So also in the same story we have the mention of Kul√ªta for L√¢·π≠a. Similarly in the story of Pushpodbhava, the sage introducing the foundling is described by Bha·π≠·π≠a N√¢r√¢ya·πáa as merely sauntering on the sea-shore, instead of his being represented as returning from his ablutions in the R√¢mat√Ærtha, and in the course of the same story Bha·π≠·π≠a N√¢r√¢ya·πáa mentions only a Yavana-dv√Æpa instead of K√¢la-yavana-dv√Æpa. These discrepancies in the matter of geographical places are important to show that the mention of places was more a matter of fancy than as resting on any degree of probability. The author of the P√ªrvap√Æ·π≠hik√¢ never seems to have been troubled with any thought as to the plausibility of his stories; neither the distance from the Vindhyas of the spots at which the foundlings were picked up, nor the fatigue of a long journey over hill and dale, nor the utter helpless and weak condition of the little babes being matters of any consequence.

Bha·π≠·π≠a N√¢r√¢ya·πáa’s consistency.

  1. The foundlings introduced in Bha·π≠·π≠a N√¢r√¢ya·πáa’s narrative again follow exactly the order of Da·πá·∏çin’s story and the consistency of his brief introduction is clearly established by the circumstance that Pramati is described as the son of K√¢map√¢la by the Yakshi·πá√ÆT√¢r√¢vali in conformity to Da·πá·∏çin’s own statement in the Fifth Uchchhv√¢sa.

Then again Bha·π≠·π≠a N√¢r√¢ya·πáa speaks of the recovery of R√¢jasi·πÉha’s lost kingdom ‚Äúthrough the favour of V√¢madeva." This statement is important, because it leaves no room for the ≈öesha or Uttarap√Æ·π≠hik√¢, referred to in para. 5 above. So also the story of S√¢mba at p. 27 (11. 18-24) is anticipated by Bha·π≠·π≠a N√¢r√¢ya·πáa, and Rajaha·πÉsa is assured by a sage of R√¢jav√¢hana’s elevation to paramount sovereignty after his captivity for two months. The Purvap√Æ·π≠hika describes the marriage of Avantisundar√Æ with R√¢jav√¢hana as being brought about by a magician, but Bha·π≠·π≠a N√¢r√¢ya·πáa says that the hero simply found an opportunity of entering the princess’ apartment while the magician was exhibiting a thunder-storm.

Moreover the last two sentences of Bha·π≠·π≠a N√¢r√¢ya·πáa’s Introductions often the abruptness of Da·πá·∏çin’s own narrative by the mention of a previous conversation between the lovers and the reference to a ≈ö√¢stric injunction prescribing a description of the Universe as a means of winning over the affection of a young damsel.

Bha·π≠·π≠a N√¢r√¢ya·πáa difficult to identify.

** **14. It is difficult to say definitely who this Bha·π≠·π≠a N√¢r√¢ya·πáa was, unless we have incontrovertible evidence to fix the date of the composition of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita itself. The Bha·π≠·π≠a N√¢r√¢ya·πáa of the Ve·πá√Æ-Sa·πÉh√¢ra seems to be altogether out of the question, since the pedantry and penchant for alliteration which distinguish every sentence of this Introduction are hardly in keeping with the style of the Ve·πá√Æ-Sa·πÉh√¢ra. Aufrecht mentions 29 authors who bore thatname. If not a contemporary‚Äôthis Bha·π≠·π≠a N√¢r√¢ya·πáa must have lived at least very near Da·πá·∏çin’s own time.

The S’esha or concluding section.

  1. Mention has already been made of the concluding part known as ‚Äò≈öesha’the work of a Deccan Pa·πádit by name Chakrap√¢·πái D√Ækshita, about whom nothing is known. Pandit R. V. Krishnam√¢ch√¢rya, a well-known Sanskrit scholar known as Abhinava-B√¢·πáa, speaks of a ninth Uchchhv√¢sa written by one Padman√¢bha and published at Madras. Professor Wilson mentions (P. 30 Intro.) a concluding chapter by one Gop√Æn√¢tha , which the Professor seems to have examined and rejected as being ‚Äúnot of great interest." This Gop√Æn√¢tha is mentioned by Aufrecht as Gop√Æn√¢tha Kavir√¢ja and as the author of (1) ‡§¶‡§∂‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§•‡§æ (A. D. 1677.) and some other works. On the whole, we feel inclined to hold that the P√ªrvap√Æ·π≠hik√¢ is not the work of Da·πá·∏çin.

Let us now proceed to a consideration of the work itself.

DA≈öAKUM√ÇRACHARITA.

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

( A ) INTERNAL EVIDENCE.

  1. Who was Da·πá·∏çin, the author of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita, is a very hard question to decide, and before we proceed to a discussion of the same, it is necessary to examine the internal evidence afforded by the work itself.

Such an examination of the work will help us in arriving at some solution of the question of authorship.

Internal evidence of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita.

Since Da·πá·∏çin, the author of the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa, has been assumed till now to be also the author of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita, we propose to conduct our examination of the Da≈õakumaracharita in the light of the precepts laid down in the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa itself. We propose to confine the test to the work proper, leaving out of consideration the P√ªrvap√Æ·π≠hik√¢ which most scholars concur in ascribing to other hands.

The essential requisite of good composition.

  1. The author of the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa warns all aspirants to poetic fame against connivance at even the most trivial flaws in composition, and illustr√¢tes his meaning by comparing even a single fault to ‚Äúa spot of white leprosy which mars the beauty of the whole person." ‡§§‡§¶‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ç‡§ö‡§®‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•à‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡•• K√°v. I. 7.

Violation of Grammar and idiom.

  1. With such a general test of good composition before us, is it possible to defend such (A) ungrammaticalforms as:‚Äî

(1) ‡§ö‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç and ‡§Ü‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç p. 34-1. 7-8.
(2) ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç p. 72‚Äì1. 8.
(3) ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§∑‡§§ p. 92-1. 8.
(4) ‡§Ü‡§π‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡§§ p. 92-1. 9.
(5) ‡§â‡§™‡§ó‡•Ç‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø p. 106-1. 8.
(6) ‡§Ü‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø p. 128-1. 1
(7) ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç p. 133 - 1. 23.

or such (B) ungrammatical constructions as:-

(1) ‡§è‡§®‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ p. 35-1. 12.
(2) ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡§Æ‡•á p. 81-1. 19.
(3) ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•á p. 139 -1. 24?

or (C) such irregular syntax as in the following sentences :‚Äî

(1) ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ö‡§ø ‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§ï‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§É p. 64-1.6.
(2) ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ñ‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§π ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§ P. 66-1. 8.
(3) ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡§π‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à ‡§®‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ p. 69-1.11.
(4) ‡§Æ‡§ò‡§µ‡§§‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç p. 88- 1. 7.
(5) ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ã ‡§ú‡§®‡§®‡•Ä p. 95-1. 4 ; ‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡§ñ‡•Ä…..‡§ï‡§®‡§ï‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡§æ, plural for singular p. 123- 1. 8.
(6) ‡§â‡§™‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡•çP. 96 -1. 13.
(7) ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ p. 140-1. 22. (Without some such word as ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ?

or (D) such lapses in idiom as:‚Äî

(1) ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§É p. 103 -1. 6.
(2) ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú ‡§â‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§Ø‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç p. 116 -1. 9?

or (E) such unfamiliar use of words as:‚Äî

(1) ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§£‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡§£‡•á p. 41-1. 1.
(2) ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç p. 85-1. 22. for sending a message.
(3) ‡§Ö‡§•‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§§‡•Å p.101-1. 5. for calling on a prince to begin his narrative.
(4) ‡§ö‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç p. 121- 1. 14.
(5) ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§ß‡§Æ‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç p. 140-1. 8.

or (F) such misuse of words as:‚Äî

(1) ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§Ép. 35-1. 12. as applied to a Kshatriya who pretended to be a Brahmin.
(2) ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§∞for ‚Äòthere’ p. 115-1. 1.
(3) ‡§â‡§™‡§∞‡§ø p. 117-1. 1 for ‘after’ without any word to govern.
(4)‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∂p. 127-1. 21. for ‚ÄúKing of the country‚Äù? We have culled these instances of bad grammar and faulty idiom only to show that an authority on Rhetoric to whom even trivial literary blemishes were like ‘spots of white leprosy’ could not possibly have sinned so grievously in his own composition, knowing that his own work would be cited by others against his own dicta.

  1. Besides all the lapses we have cited above, there is one more specific departure from the precepts of the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa. Though as a general

another departurefrom the rules of thek√¢vy√¢dar≈õa

rule, Da·πá·∏çin insists upon perspicuity of style ( ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§¨‡§§‡•ç &c. K√¢v. I. 45) he considers ‚Äúelaborateness of style" ( ‡§ì‡§ú‡§É) as the “soul of prose‚Äù ( ‡§ì‡§ú‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç I. 80 ). Now, as a matter offact, the Da≈õakum√¢racharita is much easier anddecidedly less elaborate than even the Harshacharita. Except where describing the personal charms of a heroine or some particular pose as in Kanduk√¢vat√Æ’s dance (p. 104) or some weird or picturesque scene, he seldom uses long and unwieldy compounds.

Nor does it appear likely that the author of the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa would have indulged in that literary tour de force of which the seventh Uchchhv√¢sa is such a notable example. And what by the way can we say of the motive assigned for resorting to such literary acrobatics ?

Bad taste.

  1. Thus far in regard to the mere use of words and expressions;but a more flagrant transgression of the rules laid down in the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa is to be found in the manner and matter and in the development of Rasa or Emotion.

The author of the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa was a purist- both in style and sentiment. To him perspicuity of diction was as dear as chastity of thought. His literary taste was as refined as our own and he would not tolerate such words as ‘spitting’ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ó‡•å‡§£‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡§æ‡§π‡§§‡•á‡••K√¢v. I 95., much less describe one of his heroes as spitting after chewing betel-leaf on a white-washed wall at the foot of the sofa on which he sees his love sleeping. (Vide Da≈õak. p. 63,11. 6, 7). Though the spit is shown as making on the wall a likeness of a Chakrav√¢ka bird, the very idea of spitting did not evidently strike the author of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita as vulgar, apart from such a thing being considered an affront to his lady-love.

Indelicacy.

  1. The dicta of the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa in the matter of expurgating whatever savoured of indelicacy or vulgarity are such as will commend themselves tothe most fastidious critic of the West. For instance, “the delectableness of every expression of thought”, says he ‚Äúdepends mainly on the absence of impropriety, whatever embellishments of style may be used to make the meaning attractive.” ( ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•à‡§µ‡•à‡§®‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§π‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§æ‡••K√¢v. I. 62. ) Not content with merely a general caveat against impropriety, he illustrates the above rule by condemning even such an apparently harmless sentence as " How dost thou, O Girl!not love me, who love thee? " ( ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ K√¢v. I. 63. )

Even such a bald or blunt sentence is in his opinion " repellent.‚Äù ( ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•á )‡•§Ibid. If we place side by side with this dictum the very offensive verse ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§≤‡§ø &c., (p. 63-1. 4 Da≈õak.) can we in our heart of hearts believe that the same Dan·πá·∏çin who laid down the rule also composed such a lewd verse ?

The author of the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa is stern in denouneing not only the general meaning of a passage, but even the use of a single indelicate word. For, says he, " there is vulgarity even in the use of a single word if it suggests anything improper ( ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§∏‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§ K√¢v. I. 65 ). " Even an innuendo or equivocation either by the trick of joining words or by implication was abhorrent to him " ( ‡§™‡§¶‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É‡•§ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§K√¢v. I. 66 ). If these canons of good taste were applied to the Da≈õakum√¢racharita how can we justify the many improper passages which disfigure the work ? When these passages are carefully considered, the conviction grows upon one that Da·πá·∏çin, so well known and so highly respected as an authority on Rhetoric, could not, without stultifying himself, have so far forgotten his own precepts as to violate in practice what he taught in theory:

Subject-matter.

  1. If the diction and style and bad taste of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita give the lie direct to the teaching of the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa, what can we say of the subject-matter ? Gambling, burglary, murder, impersonation, abduction and illicit love are jointly or severally the predominant incidents in every story and one is surely justified in asking oneself whether the author of the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa meant these stories to be a practical illustration of his own precepts. A K√¢vya in his opinion should have a good subject ( ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ) drawn from history or popular tale or from othersources; it should depend upon the fruit of the fourfold objects of life and the hero should be both clever and noble:( ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡§•‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa 1. 15). Can we say that the stories of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita fulfil any one of these conditions ?

Besides all that we have urged above, a comparison of the K√¢vy√¢da≈õa and the Da≈õakum√¢racharita brings to light an instance which to us appears to be a clear indication of a non-identity of the authorship of these two works. In the second Parichchheda of the K√¢vy√¢da≈õa occurs the following verse:‚Äî

‡§∏‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§• ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•§
‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡••

At page 105-11. 18-19. ( U. VI. ) of the Da≈õakum√°racharita we have the following sentences:‚Äî ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ‡•à‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§

It may be noted that the idea in both is the use of a collyrium. In the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa, the collyrium is described as making a person “invisible”. The Da≈õakum√¢racharita carries the idea further and makes the collyrium to have the property of making the person using it “look like an ape.‚Äù In the former, the idea is put elegantly and grammatically. In the latter the same is expressed clumsily and ungrammatically. If the author of the former work had also written the latter, would he have thus sinned both against grammar and perspicuity ?

The author ofK√¢vy√¢dar≈õa is not probably the author of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita

  1. This examination of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita with special reference to the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa, is to our mind sufficiently strong evidence of the improbability of both these works having proceeded from the same pen. Let us now see if the hypothesis we have attempted to raise can find any support, also from the plot and the general tenour of the work.

The plot.

  1. The plot consists of a number of tales loosely strung together with a single thread running through them all, viz., the acquisition of paramount sovereignty. The hero of each story is a friend of R√¢jav√¢hana and each one becomes by some means the de facto ruler of a separate kingdom. The means employed in each case are execrable, a violent death of the actual ruler and a clandestine marriage with the Queen or a Princess being the main incidents of each tale. As far as Da·πá·∏çin’s own narrative goes, the seven Kum√¢ras who are R√¢jav√¢hana’s friends and associates lay at the feet of their royal master their own rights as rulers, each one having, in the course of carving out his career, secured a princely spouse. They all unite in assisting Si·πÉhavarm√¢, the King of A·πÖga, against Cha·πá·∏çavarm√¢, Viceroy of the King of Malwa, and have the honour of meeting their royal master and the satisfaction of receiving his congratulations on their ingenuity and prowess.

The tenour of the work.

  1. We have in a previous section referred to the bad taste of the author in reference to the style and sentiment, but our attempt at estimating the literary merit of the work, would be one-sided and incomplete without an examination of its moral tone. Men and women may be wicked and an author may be permitted to paint them as they are in their true colours, but when an author stoops to justify what is immoral, he plays the part of an advocatus diaboli and cannot hope to escape censure. For instance, what can we say of an author who ferrets out or invents a story purporting to justify adultery and invokes the blessing of a deity on such unhallowed intercourse (p. 79, 1. 9) ? A mind that could conceive such a situation and a society that applauds such open advocacy of immorality are justly considered to be on the verge of degeneracy.

  2. Prof. Wilson and Mark Collins seem to have attached some importance to the geography of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita. We have already referred to the mention of ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§•, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§µ‡§® and ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§∞‡•Ä in the P√ªrvap√Æ·π≠hik√¢. What weight can be attached to the. geographical accuracy of the P√ªrvap√Æ·π≠hik√¢, when one considers the description of the Kingdom of ‡§â‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§Ø‡§ø‡§®‡•Äas ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç( p. 22, 11. 5-6 ) ? Mention is, indeed, made of no less than 18 different countries in the course of Da·πá·∏çin’s own narrative, but except in the case of the countries referred to in the Seventh and Eighth Uchchhv√¢sas, there is nothing to show that the author knew them familiarly. It

The author of the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa is stern in denouncing not only the general meaning of a passage, but even the use of a single indelicate word. For, says he, ‚Äúthere is vulgarity even in the use of a single word if it suggests anything improper ( ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§∏‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§K√¢v. I. 65 ). ‚Äú Even an innuendo or equivocation either by the trick of joining words or by implication was abhorrent to him " (‡§™‡§¶‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É‡•§ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§K√¢v. I. 66 ). If these canons of good taste were applied to the Da≈õakum√¢racharita how can we justify the many improper passages which disfigure the work? When these passages are carefully considered, the conviction grows upon one that Da·πá·∏çin, so well known and so highly respected as an authority on Rhetoric, could not, without stultifying himself, have so far forgotten his own precepts as to violate in practice what he taught in theory:

Subject-matter.

  1. If the diction and style and bad taste of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita give the lie direct to the teaching of the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa, what can we say of the subject-matter? Gambling, burglary, murder, impersonation,abduction and illicit love are jointly or severally the predominant incidents in every story and one is surely justified in asking oneself whether the author of the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa meant these stories to be a practical illustration of his own precepts. A K√¢vya in his opinion should have a good subject ( ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ) drawn from history or popular tale or from other sources; it should depend upon the fruit of the fourfold objects of life and the hero should be both clever and noble:(‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡§•‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa 1. 15). Can we say that the stories of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita fulfil any one of these conditions ?

Besides all that we have urged above, a comparison of the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa and the Da≈õakum√¢racharita brings to light an instance which to us appears to be a clear indication of thenon-identity of the authorship of these two works. “In the second Parichchheda of the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa occurs the following verse:‚Äî

‡§∏‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§• ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•§
‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•• II.15.

At page 105-11. 18-19. (U. VI. ) of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita we have the following sentences:‚Äî ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ‡•à‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§

It may be noted that the idea in both is the use of a collyrium. In the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa, the collyrium is described as making a person “invisible”. The Da≈õakum√¢racharita carries the idea further and makes the collyrium to have the property of making the person using it “look like an ape.‚Äù In the former, the idea is put elegantly and grammatically. In the latter the same is expressed clumsily and ungrammatically. If the author of the former work had also written the latter, would he have thus sinned both against grammar and perspicuity ?

The author of K√¢vy√¢darsa is not probably the author of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita.

  1. This examination of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita with special reference to the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa, is to our mind sufficiently strong evidence of the improbability of both these works having proceeded from the same pen. Let us now see if the hypothesis we have attempted to raise can find any support, also from the plot and the general tenour of the work.

**The plot. **

  1. The plot consists of a number of tales loosely strung together with a single thread running through them all, viz., the acquisition of paramount sovereignty. The hero of each story is a friend of R√¢jav√¢hana and each one becomes by some means the de facto ruler of a separate kingdom. The means employed in each case are execrable, a violent death of the actual ruler and a clandestine marriage with the Queen or a Princess being the main incidents of each tale. As far as Da·πá·∏çin’s own narrative goes, the seven Kum√¢ras who are R√¢jav√¢hana’s friends and associates lay at the feet of their royal master their own rights as rulers, each one having, in the course of carving out his career, secured a princely spouse. They all unite in assisting Si·πÉhavarm√¢, the King of A·πÖga, against Cha·πá·∏çavarm√¢, Viceroy of the King of Malwa, and have the honour of meeting their royal master and the satisfaction of receiving his congratulations on their ingenuity and prowess.

The tenour of the work.

  1. We have in a previous section referred to the bad taste of the author in reference to the style and sentiment, but our attempt at estimating the literary merit of the work, would be one-sided and incomplete without an examination of its moral tone. Men and women may be wicked and an author may be permitted to paint them as they are in their true colours, but when an author stoops to justify what is immoral, he plays the part of an advocatusdiaboli and cannot hope to escape censure. For instance, what can we say of an author who ferrets out or invents a story purporting to justify adultery and invokes the blessing of a deity on such unhallowed intercourse (p. 79, 1. 9)? A mind that could conceive such a situation and a society that applauds such open advocacy of immorality are justly considered to be on the verge of degeneracy.

  2. Prof. Wilson and Mark Collins seem to have attached some importance to the geography of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita. We have already referred to the mention of ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§•, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§µ‡§® and ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§∞‡•Ä in the P√ªrvap√Æ»õhik√¢. What weight can be attached to thegeographical accuracy of the P√ªrvap√Æ»õhik√¢, when one considers the description of the Kingdom of ‡§â‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§Ø‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä as ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç (p. 22, 11. 5-6 ) ?Mention is, indeed, made of no less than 18 different countries in the course of Da·πá·∏çin’s own narrative, but except in the case of the countries referred to in the Seventh and Eighth Uchchhv√¢sas, there is nothing to show that the author knew them familiarly. Itmay be noted that the name ‡§ã‡§∑‡•Ä‡§ïas one of the countries mentioned in the south, though mentioned by Var√¢hamihira, is not found in later authorities.

  3. Notwithstanding all we have said above, it must be conceded that there is a good deal to be said on the bright side, though it cannot redeem the grossness of the picture as a whole.

The style.

The style is generally fluent and the choice of words appropriate and sometimes very charming. Some of his sentences such as (1) ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É( p. 78, 1. 9); (2) ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ( p. 64, 1. 2 ) &c.. are very pithy and are justly admired.

The literary tour de force which, though not in keeping with the spirit of the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa, displays great skill and mastery of vocabulary.

Along with a plentiful vocabulary and skill in the use of words, the author no doubt possessed considerable imagination and his descriptions of sunrise on pp. 51 and 68 and sunset on pp. 46, 71 and 125 are worthy of praise. So also is the imagery with which he describes the strange apparition which met the gaze of Arthap√¢la when he was suddenly brought face to face with Ma·πáikar·πáik√¢in the subterranean chamber, P. 88-89. In fact, it would appear that the author had in him all the making of a good poet but for his erotic tendency. He seems to have specially affected V√¢tsy√¢yana’s K√¢mas√ªtra and the Kau·π≠il√Æyam. The former gave to his imagination a taint of sensualism and the latter warped his judgment of right and wrong.

The work on the whole contains evidence sufficient to point to some author other than Da·πá·∏çin of the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa and we shall now proceed to some other evidence in the same direction.

(B) EXTERNAL EVIDENCE.

The influence of theK√¢vy√¢dar≈õa discernible Kavir√¢ja M√¢rga.

  1. Professor K. B. Pathak at p. 13 of the Introduction to his edition of Nripatu·πÖga’s Kavir√¢ja-M√¢rga, a K√¢narese Work on Ala·πÉk√¢ra has shown that six verses in N·πõipatu·πÖga’s Kavir√¢ja-M√¢rga are literal translations of corresponding verses of the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa. We give below the name of each of the Ala·πÉk√¢ra and the reference to both the K√¢narese work and the Sansk·πõit original side by side:‚Äî

[TABLE]

After quoting these parallel passages Professor Pathak goes on to add (p. 19, Introduction) ‚Äúthat most of the verses in the Third Parichchheda of the Kavir√¢ja-M√¢rga are either translations or adaptations from the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa.‚Äù‚ÄúNor do we fail,‚Äùcontinues he ‚Äúto recognise his influence in other parts of the work.‚ÄùThis is convincing evidence of N·πõipatu·πÖga’s familiarity with the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa and the debt he owed to the author of the Sanskrit original.

Absence of mention in the Kavir√¢ja M√¢rga.

  1. What is more pertinent to our present inquiry is the question whether any trace of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita is found in N·πõipatu·πÖga’s work. Prof. Pathak refers (p. 13) to N·πõipatu·πÖga’s ‚Äúextolling‚Äù B√¢·πáa’s two works, Harshacharita and K√¢dambar√Æ, as masterpieces of Sanskrit prose. But there is absolutely no mention of the prose-work of a Sanskrit author from whom he has borrowed so much in his own work on Ala·πÉk√¢ra. Is it possible that N·πõipatu·πÖga knew not the Da≈õakum√¢racharita or if he did, did he deliberately ignore it? Neither of the two inferences is, we think, justified. To us it appears more likely that the Da≈õakum√¢racharita was simply non-existent. This absence of any mention in N·πõipatu·πÖga’s work should also suffice to dispose of the argument that this work was perhaps an earlier production.

No mention by N√¢gavarman.

  1. Mr. M. A. R√¢m√¢nuja Iyangar, Kannada Translator, Mysore Educational Department, writing on 3rd July, 1914, says that “N√¢gavarm√¢ an equally good authority on Ala·πÉk√¢ra of the 12thcentury makes mention of the name of Da·πá·∏çin with Bh√¢maha, Rudra·π≠a and V√¢mana, the ancient and eminent authorities on Rhetoric “–a statement also testified to by Prof. Pathak (p. 17) but apparently there is no mention even in N√¢gavarma’s work of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita.

Chau·πá·∏çar√¢ja’sKannada “Abhinava- Da≈õakum√¢racharita” of the 13th century.

** **31. The evidence adduced till now is all of a negative character, but the Kannada language has happily preserved for us a clue to ascertaining approximately the time of this Da·πá·∏çin. Mr. R√¢m√¢nuja Iyangar already referred to states that there is a champu work in K√¢narese called “Abhinava Da≈õakum√¢racharite.” “The author is one Chau·πá·∏çar√¢ja, probably living at the close of the thirteenth century. He has in the 17th verse of the First √Ç≈õv√¢sa said ‘Da·πá·∏çin* the King of poets composed in Sanskrit a work known as Da≈õakum√¢ra-

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

* The work begins with the following verse :‚Äî

‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§≤‡•ã‡§≤‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§ï‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§∂‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ç‡•§
‡§™‡§¶‡§™‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•á‡§Ø‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§ö‡§ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡•§

It ends thus :‚Äî

‡§Æ‡§¶‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§ó‡§≤‡•á, ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡§≤‡•á, ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ó‡•§
‡§≤‡§ó‡•ã‡§¶‡§ó‡§ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§™‡•Å ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§ï‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§ß‡•§
‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§ó‡§≤‡•Å ‡§™‡•á‡§≤‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡•§
‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡•á‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ú‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ã‡§≤‡•ç‡••‡•ß‡•™‡•§‡•®‡•≠
‡§á‡§¶‡•Å ‡§®‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§µ‡§®‡§ú ‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ï‡§ø‡§∞‡§£‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ-
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§¶‡§≠‡§Ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∏‡•Ç‡§¶-
‡§®‡§®‡§Ç‡§¶‡§® ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø ‡§ö‡•å‡§Ç‡§°‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§™ ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡§µ-
‡§¶‡§∂‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§¶‡•ã‡§≤‡•ç‡••

charitam or ’the story of ten princes’ to the admiration and pleasure of readers which I have displayed as a character in a drama would the original’.”

The Telugu version by Ketana, also in the 13th century.

  1. Another great scholar, Pandit K. R. Chakravarti, Assistant Kannada Translator, Educational Department, Bangalore, speaks of a Telugu version of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita by a Telugu poet named Ketana, who assumed the name ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡§µ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Ä, presumably because he rendered the Sanskrit work of ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Ä into Telugu. He is also said to have flourished in the 13th century.*

The Sanskrit original may be assignedto the eleventh century.

  1. Now the production of two different versions in two sister languages in two contiguous provinces at about the same time, that is, in the thirteenth century seems clearly to point to the composition of the Sanskrit original within about two centuries previous at the best. If therefore we assign this Da·πá·∏çin, the author of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita to the eleventh century, we shall not be far from the mark.

References in Sanskrit works of a laterdate.

** **34. The acceptance of some such date will also account for the absence of any notice of this work in Sanskrit works on Rhetoric up to the end of the eleventh century. The only reference in Sanskrit

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

* Extract from the Andhra-Da≈õakum√°racharitam:

‡§ï‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§∂‡•å‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•Å‡§®‡§ï‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ó,
‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•á ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ö‡•á‡§£‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§® ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§£‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§Ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§ó,
‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•Å ‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ö‡•á‡§∞‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ó‡•Å‡§®‡§ü‡•ç
‡§≤‡•Å‡§ó‡§æ ‡§¶‡§∂‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•Ç‡§®‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡•§

Literature in the domain of Ala·πÉk√¢ra that we have is to be found in the citation of the opening verse of the P√ªrvap√Æ·π≠hik√¢( ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞&c.) without any mention of the author’s name in the Sarasvat√ÆKa·πá·π≠h√¢bhara·πáa. The verse is ascribed in the ≈ö√¢r·πÖgadhara-paddhati and also in the Subh√¢shita-ratna-bh√¢·πá·∏ç√¢g√¢ra to Da·πá·∏çlin but is not given under that author by Mr. Thomas in his Introduction to the Kav√Ændravacana-Samuccaya. It is quoted under √Ç≈õis as pointed out in our Note to p. 1, 11. If the verse is one of the class designated by the author of the History of Aryan Civilization as floating literature, it may possibly have been adopted as a benedictory verse at the beginning of the P√ªrvap√Æ·π≠hik√¢ as in the case of the Subh√¢shita-Prabandha of Bhoja. (Vide Note p. 1, 11.)

  1. Another reference that we have been able to trace is contained in Taru·πáa-V√¢chaspati’s commentary on K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa I. 28, where that author mentions the Da≈õakum√¢racharita asan example of Prabandhas which are included under the head of √Çkhy√¢nas. This Taru·πáa-V√¢chaspati is mentioned by Aufrecht as a writer on Ala·πÉk√¢ra and Prof. Ra·πÖg√¢ch√¢rya considers him an old commentator of some note. No other work by him is known. He seems to us from his style and his way of exposition to be a comparatively late writer.

One more reference that we have been able to trace is to be found in P√ªr·πáa-Sarasvati’s commentary on K√¢lid√¢sa’s Meghad√ªta I, 31 where in explaining the word ‘‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§ü‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É’ P√ªr·πáa-Sarasvat√Æquotes ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ( Da≈õak. p. 38, 1.2). This P√ªr·πáa-Sarasvat√Æ is not mentioned by Aufrecht. There is no doubt that he is later than Mallin√¢tha and Pandit R. V. Krishnam√¢ch√¢ri√¢r, otherwise known as Abhinava-B√¢·πáa places him in the 17th century.

There is also a reference of a very late date. Pi·πÖgal√¢rtha-Prad√Æpa of Sri Lakshm√Æn√¢tha, noticed by Sir R. G. Bhandarkar at p. Ixxiii in his Report on the Search of Sansk·πõit Mss. for the years 1887-1891, mentions a reference in that work to Da≈õakum√¢rada≈õ√¢ under the head of Var·πáav·πõitti. This ‡§™‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™ was according to Dr. Kielhorn composed in A. D. 1601. 36. Such references as these, coupled with the circumstance already referred to, viz. that of the composition of abridgments of Da≈õakum√¢racharita by Appayya D√Ækshita, Gop√Æn√¢tha Kavir√¢ja and Bha·π≠·π≠a Harimalla bespeak a comparatively late date for the composition of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita and support the internal evidence afforded by the text.

Indications of modernity in the Textitself.

  1. The B·πõihat-Kath√¢ of Gu·πá√¢dhya is, no doubt, the parent source from which many Sanskrit poets have drawn materials for their compositions;but the author of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita is generally believed, and that too with good reasons, to have drawn upon either the B·πõihat-Kath√¢-Ma√±jar√Æ of Kshemendra or the Kath√¢sarit-s√¢gara of Somadeva. The story of a boy passed off as a girl (p. 99), the story of Dh√ªmin√Æ (p. 108), that of Nitambavat√Æ (p. 115) and the so-called transformation described at p. 125 seem to be taken from either of these works as we have pointed out in the Notes. We are, however, inclined to hold that the latter work seems the more likely to have been used rather than the former, since there are many expressions, as we have pointed out in theNotes, which seem to have been borrowed directly from that work. Since the main incidents are common to both works, it is difficult to say definitely which work was used. We give below some of the incidents with references to both the works:‚Äî

The B·πõihat-Kath√¢-Ma√±jar√Æ.

(1) Three ministers and their sons Ma√±j. P. 36, V. 39.
(2) A boy sage carrying a woman to a penance forest where she is delivered of a son, P. 37, V. 50.
(3) Vindhya-V√¢sin√Æ bestowing a sword on a prince, P. 47, V. 25.
(4) A prostitute’s mother remonstrating with her daughter, P. 52, V. 87.
(5) A magician preparing to offer a Princess as a victim to Chan·πá·∏çik√¢, P. 86, V. 218.
(6) A wife in a previous birth, P. 107, V. 61.
(7) Sons of the old ministers and companions of the Prince, P. 113, V. 132-134.
(8) Vidy√¢dhara prophesying paramount sovereignty to the Prince, P. 116, V. 15.

(9) A≈õokadatta snatching an anklet from off the foot of a woman, P. 126, V.139

(10) A prince pursuing a boar goes to the nether world and marries a princess who was in the power of the boar, P. 133, V. 224.

(11) A Bhikshuk√Æ employed in winning the affection of a woman, P. 192, V. 418

(12) Sons of ministers raised to their father’s offices, P. 204, V. 560-562.

(13) A ship wrecked on the coast of Ceylon, P. 212, V. 40.

(14) A Vidy√¢dhar√Æ cursed by a sage to birth as a mortal, P. 213, V. 50.

The above are instances of such hints as mayhave been borrowed from the B·πõihat-Kath√¢-Ma√±jar√Æ.

These hints of incidents could as well have been gleaned from the Kath√¢sarits√¢gara. The following references to words and expressions, however, point to that work as the more likely source.

(1) ‡§≠‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç(Kath√¢. P. 337, V. 54).

(2) ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§ÉP. 390-391, V. 6.

(3) ‡§õ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç Ibid V. 9.

(4) ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡•ã Ibid V. 12.

(5) ‡§π‡•á‡§Æ‡§≠‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ and ‡§π‡•á‡§Æ‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•É‡§§‡§ø P. 386, V. 28-30.

These are casual references; many more can be traced in either work. It is needless to multiply them, since the only point of such a search is to find out the source from which the incidents of the different stories are drawn. The B·πõihat-Kath√¢-Ma√±jar√Æ as well as the Kath√¢sarits√¢gara both belong to the end of the eleventh century and it is a matter of no great importance to determine which of the two works could have furnished the materials.

  1. There is in the last section (p. 129, l. 11) it reference to the dynasty of Bhoja ( ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç ) which being complimentary is taken by Prof. Wilson as some evidence of the age in which the Da≈õakum√¢racharita was probably written. Wilson doubts the genuineness of this concluding section on the very slender ground of a change of style, but concedes that ‚Äúif the work be, as it stands, the composition of Da·πá·∏çin, he must have flourished some time after Bhoja‚Äînot long however‚Äîand in the time of some of his descendants.‚Äù To us this last section seems to be the most powerful part of the work and since it is meant to give a r√©sum√© of Kau·π≠ilya’s scheme of politics, the style naturally undergoes a change suited to the nature of the subject.
    We feel some hesitation in accepting this reference as pointing definitely to the celebrated King of Dh√¢r√¢. What to us appears to be the clear meaning is a reference to the Bhoja dynasty, and since the rulers of Vidarbha have been known to belong to the Bhoja family, the poet has simply given a compliment to the last King as “an ornament to the Bhoja race.” Mr. Mark Collins has indeed set up an elaborate plea to show that the Bhojas referred to here must be the V√¢k√¢·π≠akas. Says Mark Collins (p. 36. of the Geography of the Da≈õak.) “the use of the name Bhoja which both ( K√¢lid√¢sa and Da·πá·∏çin ) these authors apply to the rulers of this country (Vidarbha) finds an explanation if we assume that they wrote at a time when this dynasty was predominant in the South.‚Äù Mr. Collins has, however, assumed that the author of the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa also wrote the Da≈õakum√¢racharita, a hypothesis which to us appears to be untenable from the internal evidence of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita itself and the other data which we have set out at some length in the preceding sections.

  2. Prof. Wilson notices also two more indications of the comparative modernity of the work. Vir√ªpaka in the second Uchchhv√¢sa (p. 47) repents of having, out of disappointment in love, been a convert to Jainism and longs to return to the orthodox faith. He also notes an allusion to N√¢stikas or unbelievers in the orthodox faith at p. 127, 1. 17.

These two references appear to us to point to a time when Jainism was powerful enough to make converts.

Prof. Wilson also notices (p. 19, Introduction) the incident of the intention to defraud a Yavana merchant of the fair price of a valuable diamond,. (p. 77, l. 18). The name of the Yavana merchant in the Bombay recension is Khaniti and it is possibly formed, as hinted in the notes, of the two words ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§® + ‡§á‡§§‡§ø (‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§§‡§ø ) which by a slight elongation of the M√¢tr√¢ or mark ove ‡§®‡§Ωo as to be joined to the perpendicular m√¢tr√¢ after ‡§ñmight have been copied to look as ‡§ñ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§ø. If this was so, then Kh√¢na would clearly be an Arabic or Persian name. In the Southern recension, the name of the Yavana trader is written as ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§≠‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø which might be ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§´‡•ç‚Äî‡§á‡§§‡§ø. In √©ither case, the reference is not to some Greek but to an Arabic or Persian name.

40.Another allusion to a Yavana trader is found in the Sixth Uchchhv√¢sa (p. 106, 1. 24) where Mitragupta is picked up by a Yavana ship of which R√¢meshu was the captain. Though the name cannot be connected with any Arabic or Persian name in familiar use, there is no doubt that he was a Persian, since there is a reference in the next sentence to watering a thousand grape-plants (p. 107, l. 1). The use of the word Yavana may, moreover, be noted, since according to Sir R. G. Bhandarkar ‚Äúthe Mahomedans were for some time after the conquest of the country by them called ≈öakas by some of the Sanskrit writers and the name Yavana to designate them came into more general use afterwards,‚Äù(Report for the Search of Sanskrit Manuscripts for the years 1887-1891, p. lxviii). Thus the word Yavana stands not for a Greek but for a Mahomedan.

  1. In addition to these clear indications of modernity, there are casual references to the practices of a degenerate age, interspersed throughout the work. In line 17. p. 96, there is an account of a Brahmin watching a cock-fight. Such cock-fights were well known in P√¢ln√¢d in the Krishna District.

Mr. Robert Sewell describes N√¢yakur√¢la of Gurz√¢la witnessing a cock-fight (p. vii Appendix to Lists of Antiquities, Madras Vol. I.). At p. xxv. of the same Appendix, is described a male figure having a spear in one hand and a fighting cock in the other. The earliest date assigned to the “P√¢ln√¢ti Virula Bh√¢gavatam” from which the story is taken is 1080-1087 A. D. This reference to a cock-fight while indicating a late date incidentally also points to the Southern Presidency as the land of Da·πá·∏çin’s birth.

  1. In line 21, p. 96 there is the use of the word ‡§â‡§™‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ, a bag of leather or cloth for holding betel-nut, etc., the ingredients of a ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Ç‡§≤. The practice of habitually chewing betel-leaf is itself very modern and the use of a handy leather bag for carrying the same is still more modern, at least in the case of Brahmins.

  2. So also the mention of ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§£ for variegated carpets (p. 92.1. 13) and ‡§ï‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§ï‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§≤or saffron-coloured shawls of gold embroidery (p. 138. 1. 21) and also the use of the word ‡§≠‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤ unknown to Amarasi·πÉha and which seems to have been first incorporated by Hemachandra, all these more or less bespeak a comparatively late date. Some well-known Sanskrit scholars see in the last two words of the last line of the opening verse of the P√ªrvap√Æ·π≠hik√¢(‡§µ‡§ø‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§É) an allusion to the Mahomedan invasion of India.

  3. There is, besides, as we have pointed out in our note on 1. 23, p. 130 some indication, however slight, of the author’s having taken his cue in the harangue of Vih√¢rabhadra from Kali’s diatribe in the Naishadh√Æya, Canto xvii, 37-96. The author of the Naishadh√Æya flourished towards the end of the twelfth century and if it be admitted that the hint for Vih√¢rabhadra’s burlesque is taken from the Naishadh√Æya, this would be an additional ground for assigning the Da≈õakum√¢racharita even to the end of the twelfth century.

Objections answered.

** **45. A friend urges that the composition of the Da≈õakum√¢r√¢charita could not be placed after the ninth century. because there is a mention at p. 110. l. 5 of ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç, the ancient capital of the Cholas, as in affluent circumstances (?). In the first place, there is nothing in the text to show that the town was then in a flourishing condition. Secondly, has not the author mentioned ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä, ‡§µ‡§≤‡§≠‡•Ä, ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§§ and even ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞ itself ? At best the mention of ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç might show his more intimate acquaintance with places in the Southern Presidency.

  1. The same friend also lays some stress on thelate marriage on which the story in the fifth Uchchhv√¢sa (p. 99, 1. 9) turns. We have already shown that the story is borrowed from the Kath√¢sarits√¢gara and cannot be taken as a reference to any usage of the author’s age.

The Mallik√¢-M√¢rutapossibly borrows incidents from the Da≈õakum√¢racharita.

  1. Among the many Sanskrit authors and poets who signallised their admiration of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita may be mentioned Udda·πá·∏ça Ra·πÖgan√¢tha, the author of the Mallik√¢M√¢ruta, a Sanskrit drama professedly written after Bhavabh√ªti’s M√¢lati-M√¢dhava. This drama has been ascribed by some to the author of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita. There is, indeed, a parallelism in incidents which is well calculated to raise such a presumption and the following enumeration will interest the careful student of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita.

(1) The plot of the drama is laid in Kusumapura.
(2) M√¢ruta, the hero, received from his father the portrait of a lady which happened to resemble that of Mallik√¢, the heroine.
(3) While M√¢ruta is praying to the Goddess Gauri for success in his suit, Mallik√¢ the heroine happens to drop from the hands of a demon directly into his arms.
(4) Vi≈õv√¢vasu, a celestial friend of M√¢ruta, personates Mallik√¢ and K√¢laka·πá·π≠ha, M√¢ruta’s human friend, assumes the garb of Mand√¢kin√Æ.
(5) K√¢laka·πá·π≠ha disgusted with life prepares to throw himself from a precipice.
(6) A flamingo coursing through the sky drops a necklace which was no other than that worn by the heroine.
(7) The daughter of Vi≈õv√¢vasu is playing with balls before Gauri.
(8) M√¢ruta draws a portrait of his lady-love in the act of playing with balls.
(9) A sage curses the hero and heroine to mortal birth.
(10) The awakening of a strange consciousness of previous birth and past relations both in the hero and heroine.

The hypothesis untenable.
48. These points of similarity and the taint of indecency from which the drama is not free (see especially v. 22 of Act viii, p. 244 Jibananda’s Edition)must have suggested theascription of the authorshipof this drama to Da·πá·∏çin. But an examination of the style of this drama is sufficient to disprove such identity of the authorship of these two works. The dialogues of the drama present much greater elaboration and consequently are much harder to understand than the simpler prose narrative of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita. The verse too is equally rugged, and whosoever reads the two works together cannot fail to be convinced of the groundlessness of the suggested common authorship of these two works. But even without the internal evidence above specified, we have sufficient and very full information supported by tradition among Southern Pandits about the life and times of Udda·πá·∏ça Ra·πÖgan√¢tha, the author of the Mallik√¢-M√¢ruta.

Name and date of theauthor of theMallik√¢-M√¢ruta.

  1. Rao Saheb T. A. Gopin√¢tha Rao, M.A., Superintendent of Arch√¶ology, Trivendram, says “Udda·πá·∏ça ≈ö√¢stri was a native of the village called L√¢·π≠apura on the bank of the P√¢laru (Kshiranad√Æ), a place near K√¢√±ch√Æpura. He was the son of Bha·π≠·π≠a Ra·πÖgan√¢tha and Ra·πÖg√¢dev√Æ and belonged to the V√¢dh√ªla Gotra and the √Çpastamba S√ªtra. Though born of a respectable family, the author was a poor man and had as a consequence to seek his fortune in the √Çndhra, Karn√¢·π≠aka, Kali·πÖga, Chola, and Kerala countries. Finally, he attached himself to the Court of the Zamorin, M√¢na-Vikrama of Calicut and there he wrote his Mallik√¢-M√¢ruta. He was a contemporary of the author of Tantra-Samuchchaya who lived in the Kollaru era, year 602 (A. D. 1427).‚Äù Rao Saheb Gopin√¢tha Rao adds in a post-script that ‚Äúmany verses and sentiments are common between Kokila-Sande≈õa (another work of Udda·πá·∏ça) and the Mallik√¢-M√¢ruta which should confirm the identity of the Authors of both.‚Äù

The same account is given in Sanskrit in No. 27 of Vol. VI of the Vij√±√¢na Chint√¢ma·πái, the well-known Sanskrit Magazine conducted by Kerala Panditas.

  1. Now that the time of the composition of the Mallik√¢-M√¢ruta is definitely ascertained, we are justified in counting this Udda·πá·∏ça among the admirers of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita. In fact, it would appear that this Da·πá·∏çin of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita whoever he was, jumped into popularity as soon as the Da≈õakum√¢racharita came to be known. Poets like Udda·πá·∏ça copied and incorporated incidents from his work. Commentators like P√ªr·πáa-Sarasvat√Æ quoted passages from his work and scholars like Appayya D√Ækshita charmed away their tedium by composing abridgments of his work.

Summary.

  1. We have in the foregoing paragraphs attempted to show that‚Äî

(1) The internal evidence of language and subject-matter of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita is altogether inconsistent with the teaching of the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa and the two works could not have been written by the same author.
