‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§æ- 5‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§®‡•à‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§£‡§™‡•á‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡•ã (?) ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§π‡§Ç‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡•ã ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§É ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§É ‡§∏‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§™‡•ã‡§§‡§É ‡§´‡§≤‡§ï‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§ü‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§´‡§≤‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á‡§®‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡§æ 10‡§®‡•à‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∑‡•ã‡§°‡§∂‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§≤‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ß‡§ø‡§µ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡•§ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ‡•ç‡§£‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡§¶‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§§ ‡§∏‡•ã‡§π‡§Æ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡•Ä ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§°‡§®‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§∏‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§¶‡•à‡§µ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§® ‡§Æ‡•á‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§® 15‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§æ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§≤‡•á ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•Ä‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§§ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§™‡§æ‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§µ‡§§‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§∏‡§ï‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§ó‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ö ‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§ú‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•§ ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡•á ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡•å 20‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§µ‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§π‡§£‡§≠‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§´‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•á‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§ü‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§∏‡•É‡§§‡§æ ‡§® ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•á ‡§ö ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∏‡•à‡§∑‡§æ ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§π‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ ‡§∑‡•ã‡§°‡§∂ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ- 25‡§ß‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•á ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•á‡§∂‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ü‡§µ‡•Ä‡§¶‡§π‡§®‡§¶‡§π‡§®‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§ú‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ã‡§π‡§Æ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∏ ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡•à‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∏‡§π ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§π‡§Ç

‡§ï‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§Ø‡•à‡§∞‡§π‡•ã‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§Ø‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ö ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•å ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•à‡§µ‡§ö‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ö‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ‡§® ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§§‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§π‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ç‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö 5‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§∂‡§∞‡§∂‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ä‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ã‡§π‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§∂‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§•‡•à‡§µ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ú‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§™‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§µ‡•á‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•á‡§ï‡§∂‡§∞‡§£‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡§π‡§Æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§∞‡§π‡§∏‡§ø ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤- 10‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡•§ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§π‡§ø‡•§ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•á ‡§ú‡§®‡•á‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§≠‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ã 15‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•§ ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡•á ‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•å ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§∂‡•É‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡§∞‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§® ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•å ‡§§‡•Å ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø- 20‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•å ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§•‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§∏‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§ã‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§è‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡§£‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§∏ ‡§®‡•Ç‡§®‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡•à‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§≠‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡•Ç‡§¢‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§§- 25‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡§ó‡§≤‡§ó‡§∞‡§≤‡§∏‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤‡§ó‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§´‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•Ä‡§•‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•á(‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É)‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•á ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•à‡§ï‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§≠‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§ ‡§∏ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•á‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã

‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§¨‡§ø‡§≠‡•á‡§∑‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§¶‡•à‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§ ‡§ó‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§ò‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡§§‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•á- 5‡§®‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡§≤‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡§≤‡§ú‡§®‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§É‡•§ ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ã‡§π‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§É‡§∏‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•ã‡§™‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∂‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§®‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡§É 10‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§É‡•§ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•Ä‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡§®‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§®‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§Ø‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§ø‡§µ ‡§™‡•å‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡•á‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§§‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•Ä 15‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡•§ ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§∏‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡•å ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ê‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§ò‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡§®‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§ó‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§§‡•å‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§≤‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡•§‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú- 20‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§®‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§É‡••

‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§∞‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§§‡•ç‡••
‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•®‡•´‡•¶

<MISSING_FIG href=”../books_images/U-IMG-1722229410Screenshot2024-07-09103520.png”/>

( Dec. Col. Mss. No. 32.
1873-74.)

P. 1. L. 3. ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§™‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§É(‡§ï‡•Ç‡§™‡•ã ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§É ) hence ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§™‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§É"A mast;" ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§É ‚Äúa pole-staff;‚Äù ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§É‚Äúa death-dealing club." “The author apparently alludes to the name of the original writer, Da·πá·∏çin, by including in his initiatory benediction the word Da·πá·∏ça ‘a stick or staff ’ in a variety of applications."(Wilson).The metre of the verse is Sragdhar√¢. It is quoted in the Second Parichchheda of the Sarasvat√Æ-Ka·πát·∏•√¢bhara·πáa, P. 1. 14. (Borooah). [B√ºhler].

Wilson’s remark can hold good if the P√ªrvap√Æthik√¢ can be proved to be also the work of Da·πá·∏çi, but tradition is all the other way. Prof. Kale sees in the word ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ the result of the exploits of three men “a reference to the literary labours of three workmen.”

As pointed out by B√ºhler, the verse is quoted in the Sarasvat√Æ-Ka·πáthabhara·πáa as an instance of ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§ó‡•Å‡§£ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏, but it is note-worthy that the author’s name is not cited. It is also quoted along with five other benedictory verses at the beginning of a work called the Subh√¢shita Prabandha of Bhoja (P. 1. Dec. Col. Collection No. 248-Vis) and is cited under Ashis in the S√¢rngadharapaddhati. It may be noted that it is not cited by Mr. Thomas under Dandin.

P. 1. L. 6. ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ Nominal pres. pt. “serving as a test or standard (to all cities).” (Wilson). Mark the author’s fondness for alliteration. ¬∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ…‡§ó‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø &c.‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡§ó‡§£‡§æ‚Äì‡§∂‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‚Äì‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ " whose greatness equal to that of the ocean (which is also a mine of jewels) was manifested by the quantities of countless jewels and other articles that were constantly offered for sale and were countless”[B√ºhler].

P. 1. L. 8. ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ä ‚ÄòPatna.’ [B√ºhler]. As this city is described as the capital of Magadha and is also referred to as‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§™‡•Å‡§∞in L. 4. P. 9. and as Kusumapura in L. 14. P. 81. it seems to be the same as the Kusumapura of the Mudr√¢r√¢kshasa. (Vide P. 22, Telang’s Edition). According to Hiuen-Thsang the old capital of K√¢nyakubja was called Kusumapura. “Are we to see in this statement a hint that in former times (under the Maukharis) P√¢taliputra and K√¢nyakubja were under one Government? Or was Kusumapura an older name for Kanauj? Kusumapura appears to have been the name of the royal precinct at P√¢taliputra (Beal, Buddhist Records Vol. II. P. 83. note 4) and it is possible that if the Guptas established a more central capital for their dominions the new place and royal precinct should preserve the name of the old, and this name (as in the case of the capital of Magadha) be used to denote the town itself.” (Mark Collin’s Geographical Data of the Raghuva·πÉsa and Da≈õakum√¢racharita, P. 25).

‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞-‡§≠‡§ü-‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§É ’’ The enemy’s army is the ocean, the heroic warriors are its waves, the horses and elephants, the sharks or alligators in it and the King’s arm the churning-stick." (B√ºhler ). Note the author’s fondness for alliteration in bringing together ‡§≠‡§ü and ‡§™‡§ü‡§≤, ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó and ‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó, ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§£ and ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞ and all the following words having a ‡§®or , because of the jingle they produce.

** P. 1. L. 10.** ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‚Äò the young dancing women are the Apsar√¢s’ [B√ºhler].

P. 1. L. 11. ‡§∂‡§∞‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø. Mark the tautology involved in the use of the twelve nouns in this long compound. All those words from ‡§∂‡§∞‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Åto ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂ connote the same idea of ‘whiteness’ and the whole compound looks like a string of railway trucks! It is worthy of note that Da·πá·∏çin, the author of the K√¢vyadar≈õa condemns this sort of tautology. (Vide K√¢vyadar≈õa, IV. 2. Ra·πág√¢ch√¢rya’s Ed.)

“‡§∂‡§∞‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø down to ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂ is a Dvandva compound, then a Karmadh√¢raya and finally a Bahuvrihi. The whole qualifies ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‚Äòfame’ which is represented as ‘brilliantly white i. e., resplendent and pure.’ The ‡§Ö‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§π‡§æ‡§∏ of ≈öiva is said to be “white” because the God shows his white teeth, when he laughs. The translation of ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§π‡§æ‡§∏ should be “the glitter of ≈öiva’s teeth, when he laughs loudly” [B√ºhler].

P. 1. L. 13. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‚Äî‚Äòwho had the happiness to enjoy as his wife the earth, whose girdle is the ocean, which contains jewels as large and brilliant as Mount Meru.’(B√ºhler).

P. 1. L. 14. ‡§Ö‡§®‡§µ‡§∞‡§§‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø who maintained by his rewards for the constant performance of sacrifices Brahma·πáas who were ≈öishtas (Vide Manu XII,109, and √Çpa-stamba I. 7,208.)’ Visishta’ ’excellent and resplendent through carrying a load of sacred learning’ i.e., brahmavarchasinah.[B√ºhler].

P. 1. L. 15. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§§‡§§‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§Ç‡§∏‡§É. Note the use of the periphrasis ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§Ç‡§∏‡§É for the sun, simply for the sake of alliteration with ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§π‡§Ç‡§∏‡§É. “The swan

of the sky is the sun‚Äîa simile which occurs already in the Rig-Veda, e. g., I. 163, 9” [B√ºhler].

P. 1. L. 16. ‡§ß‡§®‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™&c. This is a compound which is inelegant according to a canon of Da·πá·∏çi, the author of the K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa. (Vide K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa I. 72.)

P. 2. L. 1. The second word ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§‡•Ä must be construed with ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§£‡•Ä, since ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä-‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§∂‡•á‡§ñ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø does not bear a double meaning, so as to be an attributive to ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§‡•Ä ‚Äòthe earth.’

** P. 2. L. 3.** ‡§≠‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§®‡•á.The vital principle which is an abstract notion can never be reduced to ashes. We must therefore take ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§® here in the sense of body‚Äîan instance of looseness in the selection of words which characterises the whole of the P√∫rvap√Æthik√¢. The word, however, seems to have been used for the jingle it makes with ‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡§®‡•á in the following expression. “Construe ‡§≠‡§Ø‡•á‡§® with ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç in line 12”[B√ºhler]. ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø refers to ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡§®,the idea being that when the body of the God of Love was burnt by the fire emanating from the forehead of ≈öiva, all the armoury of Cupid with which he conquers the world found a resting place in the limbs of Vasumat√Æ who being a woman was unassailable. If the reading ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Éis preferred, it must be taken to refer to ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§‡•Ä.

P. 2. L. 9. ‡§ú‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡§• “the victorious car of K√¢ma.” See below P. 25. L. 25. and P. 74. L. 6. (where the sameidea occurs). ‡§Ö‡§§‡§ø‡§ò‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ò‡§®‡§Çis really compared to the wheels of the chariot and not to the chariot itself. [B√ºhler].

P. 2. L. 10. ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•á ‚Äútwo plantain-stems.‚Äù ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠ “a pillar of victory‚Äù or a t·πõiumphal column.” The pillars of victory which are found in the Presidency, e. g., at Kapadvanja and Siddhapur and which belong to the times of the Chalukya dynasty of Anhilpur P√¢tan, consist of two carved columns united by a Torana, See also Forbes’ Ras M√¢l√¢ I. P. 253. seqq. [B√ºhler].

P. 2. L. 12. The adjective ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡§≤‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§æ can be construed with both ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§‡•Ä, the Earth, in which case ‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó means the body of ≈öesha, the fabled serpent, which supports the Earth, and also with ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§‡•Ä in which case ‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó means “countless enjoyments.”

P. 2. L. 14. ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É “charged with great offices” ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É[Wilson]; better “most obedient,‚Äù see the Pet. Dict. under ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‚Äî‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø “who despised on account of their firm understanding business which would have given trouble to Brihaspati.” [B√ºhler].

P. 2. L. 21. ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∞‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§•‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§∑‡•Å ‚Äútheir fathers being dead or having been received as guests in the City of Indra. [Wilson];” at present the usual euphemism for “he died” is among ≈öaivas ‡§ï‡•à‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§É‚Äù[B√ºhler].The author, however, seems to intend ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó which is more commonly supposed to be the abode of the dead.

P. 2. L. 22. ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø, with ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø (battle) ends the first Bahuvrihi, which qualifies ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø. ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ß is possibly not a grammatical blunder but intended to be a puzzle. It ought to be explained as ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‚Äúweapons giving greatness or glory” ‡§Æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡§É [B√ºhler]. But

this word ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç is found again on P. 6. L. 19. in composition with ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ. The latter word ordinarily means ‚Äúfame‚Äù and‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç must therefore be taken in its ordinary sense of “great.” The same word also occurs at P. 16. L. 10. in composition, as ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§É and some have explained it as ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶ + ‡§Ü‡§∂‡§æ, giving to the word ‡§Æ‡§π the meaning of “liberation.” But this unusual meaning of ‡§Æ‡§π appears to be inconsistent with the immediately preceding epithet ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡§É‡•§ In the preceding line the Brahmin is also described as ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§®, ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§§‡§®‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§§, and ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞; and ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§ is also described as ‡§â‡§¶‡•Ä‡§§‡§¶‡§Ø. Consequently, it is better to take the word ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç as it is, and consider this use of ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•çinstead of‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ¬∞ as a lapse on the part of the author.

** P. 2. L. 23.** ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‚Äúwho was insatiable in new battles." [B√ºhler].

P. 2. L 25. ‡§π‡§†‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø The meaning seems to be, “who were mortally afraid on account of the great noise of the army.” Wilson gives a marginal note from one of his Mss. ‡§π‡§†‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ (sic) ‡§π‡§†‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡§É(B√ºhler). Godbole’s own Sanskrit glossary in the Nir·πáayas√¢gara edition explains the expression ‡§π‡§†‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç as‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ã ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§π‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ is a very obscure word, and according to the commentators, it seems to be connected with ‡§π‡§†, which means force or violence, the expression ‡§π‡§†‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§® meaning “the involuntary hearing of sound.” ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ literally means the ‘desire to hear’ and ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§®‡§Ç would, therefore, mean the hearing of sounds without any desire or effort to hear.

P. 2. L. 26. ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‚Äú(with an army) which was hurting the heads of the snake King already tired by carrying &c. “^(‡•¶)‡§µ‡§≤ is derived from the root ‡§¨‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç for which the Pet. Dict. gives no examples, by the affix ‡§Ö‡§ö‡•ç Siddh II 320 (Pan. III. 1. 140). [B√ºhler]. The word according to Native Grammarians is derived under two Sutras ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç (Pan. V. 2. 113) and ‡§µ‡§≤‡•á (Pan. VI. 3. 118) ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•Ä‡§µ‡§≤ is formed by the same suffix.‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§≠‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡•§Godbole explains the whole compound as under :‚Äî ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§≠‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§®‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡•ã‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Ä‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§Ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§¨‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•§

P. 3. L. 2. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§É ‡§∏‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π ‡§á‡§µ a ‚Äúlike war incarnate.” [B√ºhler].

P. 3. L. 4. ‡§®‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§≠‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø. ‚ÄúThe Apsar√¢s come to the battlefields in order to choose husbands among the fallen warriors and to lead them to Indra’s heaven. The cloud of dust which hangs over the battlefield is therefore compared to a nuptial Ma·πádapa, a square enclosure, the sides of which are formed by gay coloured curtains and which is erected in front of the bride’s dwelling," [B√ºhler].

P. 3. L. 5. ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§ø must be construed with ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‘‘deafening the universe with the roll of the drums that surpassed all other sounds in the air.‚Äù[B√ºhler].

P. 3. L. 6. ‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø.These compounds are formed in accordance with the Sutras ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡•á‡§®‡•á‡§¶‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á(II.2.27) and ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•á(V. 4. 127).Compare Kielhorn’s Sanskrit Grammar S. 558.

P. 3. L. 8. ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§Ç is formed under Pa·πáini’s S√ªtra ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§û‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§É (III. 4. 36). Compare Kielhorn’s Sanskrit Grammar S. 526 b.

** P. 3. L. 9**. ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞^(‡•¶) the ocean [B√ºhler].

P. 3. L. 11. ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‚ÄòBy means of or together with the King (thy husband)’ [B√ºhler].

P. 3. L. 13. ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡§É‚Äúwho surpassed or thought himself greater than Indra in consequence of his good fortune." [B√ºhler].

P. 3. L. 14. ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç A purificatory and sacrificial ceremony observed by women in the fourth, sixth or eighth month of pregnancy, an essential part of the rite being a partition of the hair.

P. 3. L. 16. ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡•ã Our Southern Manuscript reads ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É which too does not give a good meaning. If ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø is a misreading for ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø, it may mean “one who is fit to be worshipped like the God Brahm√¢.” As it is, ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§É can only mean “one who is fit to be worshipped by the King” ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø.

P. 3. L. 18. ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø The Fakir’s or Bawa’s dress is now, as it was in olden times, a favourite disguise. Regarding the custom to send spies, see K√¢mandaka N√Ætis√¢ra XIII, 26 [B√ºhler]. ‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡•ã ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É. For ‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø See Kir√¢ta I. 1.

P. 3. L. 25. ‡§µ‡•à‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É his heart being a target of despair, i. e., his heart being filled with despair. Regarding the temple of Mah√¢k√¢la, see Pa√±chatantra note to IV. and V. p. 52. L. 11 [B√ºhler] Cf. ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ò‡§¶‡•Ç‡§§‡•á 33 and 34 for ‡§ö‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞ and ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤.

P. 4. L. 1. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§®‡§Æ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ç The epithet ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§®‡§Ç and ‡§Ö‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞are added merely for the sake of alliteration without much propriety.

P. 4. L. 5. ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§®. Parab and Kale as well as our Southern Ms. have ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® which is a better reading than ‡§¶‡•à‡§µ‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§®, since the King of M√¢lava had obtained a boon from ≈öiva. Note the solecism in the use of the word ‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø for ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø.

L. 5. ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç=Inexpedient.

P. 4. L. 11. ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§¨‡§≤ K√¢mandaka enumerates six divisione of the army, Viz., ‡§Æ‡•å‡§≤, ‡§≠‡•É‡§§, ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§ø, ‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡•ç, ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç and ‡§Ü‡§ü‡§µ‡§ø‡§ïfor. Of these ‡§Æ‡•å‡§≤ as distinguished from ‡§≠‡•É‡§§ (mercenary) seems to correspond to the modern “Militia.” K√¢mandaka. XIX. 3.

**P. 4. L. 14.**‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‚ÄòEqual to the King of immortals in battle, marked by steady skill in the use of various weapons. [Wilson].

P. 4. L. 19. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç great [B√ºhler].

P. 4. L. 20. ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡§ø‚Äì‡§§‡§§‡§ø‚Äì‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É Fatigued by the striking or use of numerous weapons. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§ÉRestored to life or revived. Parab and Kale and our SouthernMs. read ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É’Not dispossessed of life’ which is certainly a better reading.

P. 4. L. 24. ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§ø &c., Some word to say that the Ministers addressed the Queen would make the sentence more intelligible. As it is, we must take the whole clause from ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§ø in L. 24. P. 4. to ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ in L. 1. P. 5. as the ministers’ expostulation.

P. 4. L. 25. ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§É Literally flowery or courtly speeches.

P. 5. L. 1. ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§π‡•Ä‡§≤‡§Ø‡§æ joyless [B√ºhler].
P. 5. L. 4. ‡§™‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§É=‡§™‡§•‡§ø+‡§Ü‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§É

P. 5. L. 5. ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µwhich was as it were a line of death.’ The simile is taken from palmistry. The ’line of death’ stands nearly vertically on the line of life, which crosses the hand horizontally. [B√ºhler.]
P. 5. L. 6. ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‚Äúsurpassing by the sweetness of her voice the Koil" [B√ºhler].
P. 5. L. 7. ‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡•å‡§™‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§ Parab and Kale have ‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§ which is a better reading. “‡§î‡§™‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§ may be explained as a derivative from‡§î‡§™‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Øwith ‡§á‡§§.” [B√ºhler].
P. 5. L. 8. ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø &c., Cf. ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§ú‡§®‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§™‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§® ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§É‡••’ Raghuva·πÉ≈õa. XIV. 66.
P. 5. L. 11. ‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡•ã‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§â‡§™‡•ã‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ø Cf. ‡§™‡§™‡•å ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§≤‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡•ã‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç Raghuva·πÉ≈õa, II. 19.
P. 5. L. 18. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§®. Who held rejoicings.
P. 5. L. 22. ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö with her mind made up, or her resolve duly formed. The copulative‡§ö joins ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ and ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ.
‡§∏‡§Æ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø Aorist pass. of causal. See Kielhorn S. Gr. S. 430. [B√ºhler].
**P. 5. L. 23.**‡§ú‡§≤‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø “Splendid prosperity which resembles bubbles on the water, comes and disappears quickly as a brilliant flash of lightning” [B√ºhler].
P. 5. L. 25. ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ is named as the representative of the Solar race [B√ºhler]. He is considered to be the 28th of that dynasty and was celebrated for his piety and liberality and was on those accounts elevated along with his subjects to heaven.

‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞ also a King of the Solar dynasty, immortalized by the genius of V√¢lm√Æki in the famous epic, the R√¢m√¢ya·πáa.
** P. 6. L. 1.** ‡§¶‡•à‡§µ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç Misery or pain brought on by destiny.
P. 6. L. 10. ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ’ with this intention I have come to your reverence who follows the restrictive rules (laid down for ascetics) [B√ºhler].
P. 6. L. 19. ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡§≠‡§ø‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É’whose names (indicated) greatness or splendour.’ This explanation, as well as those given on P. 2. L. 22. and P. 16. L. 10. holds good only on the supposition that the author of the P√ªrvap√Æthik√¢ could write correct Sanskrit. Those who are of the contrary opinion, can point to the very bad forms ‡§Ü‡§µ‡•ã‡§ö‡§ø P. 6. L. 13, ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç P. 3. L. 10, ‡§Ö‡§¶‡§Ç‡§∂‡§ø P. 10. L. 25. which all Mss. offer. I for my part, however consider all of these blunders to be due to clerical mistakes‚Äù [B√ºhler]. See, however, our note P. 2. L. 22.
P. 6. L. 21. ‡§∞‡§∏‡•á‡§® must be construed with ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø. [B√ºhler]. This word is omitted in our Southern Ms.
P. 7. L. 1. ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•É‡§§‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø whose fame occupied the assembly of the gods. Prof. Taranath’s correction ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§ for ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•É‡§§ deserves consideration’ [B√ºhler].
P. 7. L. 5. ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§¨‡§≤‡•á ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡•á ‘His obedient army not being on the spot’ [B√ºhler]. This explanation however, does not seem to be correct, since in the very next line we have ‡§π‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡•à‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® i. e., ‚Äú with the remnant of his army." Parab and Kale adopt the reading ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á and explain the word to mean ‚Äúkilled" which

too is inconsistent with ‡§π‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑ in the next line. Instead of understanding an avagraha before ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø, as Dr. B√ºhler does, will it not be better to take the expression ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§µ‡§≤‡•á ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡•á as having an oppositional force and explain it, as ‚Äú(though) his army was obedient or under control?‚Äù

P. 7. L. 6.‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§É ‚Äúhaving in consequence of his merit, been set free out of compassion." [B√ºhler]. Strict grammatical accuracy requires the insertion of ‡§ö after ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®. Cf. ‡§Æ‡•à‡§•‡§ø‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§É in the story of ‡§â‡§™‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç P. 66. L. 11.

P. 7. L. 7. The descendants of the ≈öavaras are probably the Suars (?) of modern India. Sansk·πõit poets are not particular about the names of the aboriginal tribes. Below P. 7. L. 22. and 25, the same people are called Kir√¢tas and P. 8. L. 14. again ≈öavaras, while P. 66. L. 18. the robbers who captured Apah√¢ravarman are named Bhillas [B√ºhler]. Note also that the people who robbed the King of Mithil√¢ in the forest are called ‡§≤‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï in that passage.

P. 7. L. 8. ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§É hemmed in on all sides. ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§É. The members of the harem being saved by the feudal army or militia. ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§¨‡§≤ formed one of the six branches of a King’s army. Vide Note, ante P. 4. L. 11. Also K√¢mandaka. XIX. 3.
P. 7. L. 11. Our Southern Ms. reads ‡§â‡§¶‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡§ø and so also do Parab and Kale. We have adopted this reading in preference to the old ‡§â‡§¶‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§É, because ^(‡•¶)‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡§ø gives better sense and accounts for her stumbling.

P. 7. L. 12. ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø. For this part of the story compare below the Upah√¢ravarmacharita, Page 66. L. 15-20. ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§°‡§Æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§isgrammatically a doubtful construction. ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§ is according to Wilson ‚Äò3rd Pers. Sing. 1st Pret. Atmanepada from ‡§≤‡•Ä verb of the 4th Conjugation,’ but ‡§≤‡•Ä of that conjugation is intransitive and cannot take an object, and therefore the word ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§° must be in the locative. Compare for the story P. 66. L. 15-20. where the same account is given in slightly different words. [B√ºhler].

P. 7. L. 24. ‡§¶‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∂‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ωee Kielhorn S. Gr. S 355 b. ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äòwhile he flies on all fours’ [B√ºhler]. Parab takes ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡•à‡§É with ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡•à‡§É and this is more plausible, since it is very doubtful, if a little child after such perilous adventures could have either the strength or presence of mind to run away on all fours.‚Äù

P. 8. L. 10. ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§£‡§É ‡§∂‡§¨‡§∞‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ÉA. K. [B√ºhler].

P. 8. L. 15. ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•Ä‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§™‡•á =“‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§É ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§É, ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É " ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä.

P. 8. L. 23. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§µ‡§® By this term probably Zanzibar on the coast of Arabia is meant. (B√ºhler). This passage is specially referred to in Mookerji’s “Indian Shipping” (P. 66), but there is no attempt made at identifying this island.

It is interesting to note that in the P√ªrvap√Æt·∏•ik√¢ by Bhatta N√¢r√¢ya·πáa, (Vide Appendix) the expression is simply ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§®‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§™‡§Æ‡•ç ; so also instead of ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ, we have ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ. Whether the name of the island was given as ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§µ‡§®

and the name ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§• (P. 8. L. 20.) was introduced for poetic effect or to give the story a semblance of genuineness, it is hard to say. One thing is certain, namely, that ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ was ship-wrecked and that his infant son, hardly a few days old, was saved by V√¢madeva’s disciple and brought with the mother all the way from the sea-shore to the fastnesses of theVindhya Mountains.

To make the story credible, it is necessary to locate ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§µ‡§® as near the Vindhyas as possible, and it must also have adjacent to it some holy place called after R√¢ma. Alexander is said by √Çrian to have passed through a village called R√¢mb√¢kia which Cunningham has identified with “R√¢mb√¢gh in the Aghor valley, in which the principal sacred places are connected with the history of R√¢ma, the great hero of the R√¢m√¢ya·πáa.” (Mc’ Crindle’s Invasion of India by Alexander P. 168). In the course of his voyage down the Western arm of the Indus from P√¢t√¢la, Alexander reached an island where his fleet met with a mishap similar to that described in the text (Vide P. 258 Me’ Crindle). If the island ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§µ‡§® is ‚ÄòKillouta of √Çrrian’ (Mc’ Crindle P. 164), the story has a semblance of plausibility.

P. 9. L. 1. Note the alliteration in ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä and ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä as well as ^(‡•¶)‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡•ã and ^(‡•¶)‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ø‡•ã in the preceding line.

P. 9. L. 15. ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•á‡§£ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•á‡§§ Pa·∏ç.

P. 9. L. 18. ‡§´‡§≤‡•á‡§§‡§∞‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ because (he found that the child was) not a fruit.’ (B√ºhler). See P. 20. lines 10 to 15 for the same story.

P. 10. L. 4. ‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‚Äúa Yaksha woman” (B√ºhler). For the same story, See P. 82. L. 15-20.

P. 10. L. 10. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø having named.

P. 10. L. 12. ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äúwho had obtained or possessed a splendour equal to that of the gods [B√ºhler].

The epithet might as well be taken with ‡§®‡§∞‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç in which case ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç should be taken in its ordinary sense of fame. Wilson, Godbole and Kale insert another epithet ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø between ^(‡•¶)‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø and ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç. Our Southern Ms. does not give the epithet and we have preferred to follow B√ºhler.

‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø literally “having brought near.‚Äù

P. 10. L. 20. ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡§∞ “a village or land given to a Brahmin for his maintenance” [B√ºhler].

P. 10. L. 25. ‡§Ö‡§¶‡§Ç‡§∂‡§ø. We have adopted this reading on the authority of our Southern Ms. Wilson, Parab and Kale also read ‡§Ö‡§¶‡§Ç‡§∂‡§ø in place of the inaccurate form ‡§Ö‡§¶‡§Ç‡§∂‡§ø of the old edition.

P. 11. L. 2. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§¢‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ=her limbs being inflamed by the flame i. e. heat of the virulent poison.

P. 11. L. 12. Regarding Chaula and Upanayana, see e. g., √Ç≈õval√¢yana Grihya S√ªtra I. 17, and 19 seqq [B√ºhler].

P. 11. L. 14. ‡§Ü‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ï ‘Episodes’ and ‡§Ü‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‘stories’ like the K√¢dambari. See also ‘Da·πá·∏çin’ K√¢vy√¢dar≈õa I. 23. seqq on the difficulty of distinguishing between a ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ and ‡§Ü‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ. As a matter of fact Da·πá·∏çi con-

siders ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ and ‡§Ü‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ as one with only two names (‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡§æ) K√¢vy√¢d I. 28. In the text the word is ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§•‡§æ which the Pa·∏ç. explains as ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§•‡§æ.

P. 11. L. 15. ‡§ï‡•å‡§ü‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§ü‡§≤is Ch√¢·πáakya’s Da·πádan√Æti. Compare also note to Pa√±chatantra II. and III. P. 10. L. 7. [B√ºhler].

P. 11. L. 18. “The Institutes of thieving and gambling were very necessary for the heroes of the Da≈õakum√¢racharita, as their subsequent adventures show. The work on the art of house-breaking is ascribed to Kar·πá√Æ-suta. See below note to P. 48. L. 4. and P. 65. L. 6. (Text).” [B√ºhler].

P. 11. L. 19. ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‘Having acquired proficiency (in all these branches of learning) from teachers or professors of the same.’ This clearly implies an army of teachers, but what is more noteworthy is that there were regular instructors in the black arts such as magic, and such nefarious professions as house-breaking, thieving and gambling !

The whole passage is noteworthy as the author’s ideal of a prince’s education. The vitiated taste, possibly the reflex of the degeneracy of the age in which the author lived, is forcibly and strikingly seen when this ideal of a prince’s education is compared with that set forth in the K√¢dambari. The latter has an addition of 25 more arts, some of which are remarkable and well worthy of being included in the range of studies befitting a prince. It may
also be noted that the black arts of magic and the

sinister arts of thieving and gambling find no place in Ba·πáa’s list of the accomplishments of a prince.

It will be an interesting question to fix, however approximately, the age in which this degeneracy set in. In a work called Prabandhako≈õa composed by R√¢jasekhara, son of Abhaya, and pupil of Tilakasuri about the year, A. D. 1270 at Delhi, the following very interesting list of the subjects studied by Ama, son of Ya≈õodhara King of K√¢nyakubja, occurs at page 10 (Vide Ms. No. 363, 1871-72 Dek. Col. Col.)

‡•ß ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ó‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•® ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•© ‡§®‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•™ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡•´ ‡§™‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•¨ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•≠ ‡§õ‡§Ç‡§¶‡§É ‡•Æ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•Ø ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡•ß‡•¶ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•ß‡•ß ‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•ß‡•® ‡§®‡§ø‡§ò‡§Ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§É ‡•ß‡•© ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•ß‡•™ ‡§®‡§ñ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•ß‡•´ ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡•ß‡•¨ ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§É ‡•ß‡•≠ ‡§ó‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§π‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•ß‡•Æ ‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§π‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•ß‡•Ø ‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡•®‡•¶ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§É ‡•®‡•ß ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§É ‡•®‡•® ‡§∞‡§∏‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§É ‡•®‡•© ‡§ñ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§É ‡•®‡•™ ‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•®‡•´ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•®‡•¨ ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§É ‡•®‡•≠ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡•®‡•Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§É ‡•®‡•Ø ‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§°‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•©‡•¶ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•©‡•ß ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•©‡•® ‡§Ü‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•©‡•© ‡§Ü‡§ó‡§Æ‡§É ‡•©‡•™ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•©‡•´ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•©‡•¨ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡•©‡•≠ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•©‡•Æ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§É ‡•©‡•Ø ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§É ‡•™‡•¶ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡•™‡•ß ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§É ‡•™‡•® ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡•™‡•© ‡§ñ‡•á‡§ö‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ ‡•™‡•™ ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ ‡•™‡•´ ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•™‡•¨ ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§≤‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡•™‡•≠ ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•™‡•Æ ‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§É ‡•™‡•Ø ‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ ‡•´‡•¶ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡•´‡•ß ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä ‡•´‡•® ‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡•´‡•© ‡§™‡§£‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡•´‡•™ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ò‡§ü‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•´‡•´ ‡§™‡§æ‡§∑‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡•´‡•¨ ‡§≤‡•á‡§™‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡•´‡•≠ ‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡•´‡•Æ ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§∏‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡•´‡•Ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•¨‡•¶ ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡•¨‡•ß ‡§π‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•¨‡•® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•¨‡•© ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•¨‡•™ ‡§™‡•à‡§∂‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•¨‡•´ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§∂‡§É ‡•¨‡•¨ ‡§ï‡§™‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•¨‡•≠ ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§æ ‡•¨‡•Æ ‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡•¨‡•Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§É ‡•≠‡•¶ ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§É.

Some of these names are unintelligible, but ‡§ñ‡•á‡§ö‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ, ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ, ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§≤‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø, ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç seem to mark the downward tendency of the age in which faith in occultism seems to have gained such a hold on the public mind as to have necessitated the inclusion of such arts in the scheme of a prince’s education.

<MISSING_FIG href=”../books_images/U-IMG-1722346329Screenshot2024-07-30115049.png"/>

SECOND UCHCHHV√ÇSA.

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1722318185Screenshot2024-07-09103520.png"/>

P. 12. L. 2. ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ã‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ lit. “formed as if he were a brother” of the god of love.

‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§∏‡§æ‡§™‡§π‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ’ who put to shame K√¢rtikeya by their valour.’ [B√ºhler]. We would prefer to render ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§∏ by ‘daring."

** P. 12. L. 2.** ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§™‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‘With the palm of the hand marked with lines representing a victorious banner, an umbrella and a thunderbolt.’ ‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡•á ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§õ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§≤‡•á ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•• ‡§ß‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•å ‡§™‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§• ‡§§‡•ã‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§ö ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§ö ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

The sole of the foot is also described by poets as having these marks. Cf. ‡§§‡•á ‡§∞‡•á‡§ñ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§≤‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç Raghu. IV. 88.

** P. 12. L. 4.**‡§®‡§ø‡§ú…..‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äòwhose locks became the bees that alighted on his two lotus feet.’ The boys according to the rule of the Dharma ≈ö√¢stras, came to embrace (upasa·πÉg·πõih) the feet of the sage and their long black locks consequently covered the latter “[B√ºhler] ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú must be taken with ‡§§‡•á‡§® in L. 4.

** P. 12. L. 6.** ‡§Ü‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø must be taken with ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ in L. 1.

P. 12. L. 10. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ…… ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§É The whole of this sentence is a notable example of alliteration of which the author was so fond. Note the recurrence of (1) ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ (2) ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ ( 3 ) ‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ (4) ‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã ( 5 ) ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ and ( 6 ) ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§É whose exploits equalled those of whom R√¢ma was the foremost.‚Äù

P. 12. L. 11. ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‚Äòby marching has to be taken with ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§Ç ‚ÄòExpectant of glory,’ the meaning is that the King hoped to see his fortune restored by the expedition of the princes [B√ºhler].

P. 12. L. 11. ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø Having appointed others to be his ministers.

P. 12. L. 15. ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äúwho manifested (in the ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç marks on his body) the prowess of a Kir√¢ta.‚Äù Note the antithesis between this and the preceding epithet, Note also that the leaders of such fallen Brahmins are mentioned as Pulindas, while their appearance is described as resembling that of Kir√¢tas.

P. 12. L. 20. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§™‡•å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ò‡•ç‡§®‡§û‡•ç Pan. V. 2. 37.

P. 12. L. 23. see note L. 15 above. “Observe again the uncertainty of the author regarding the name of the tribe of aborigines with whom M√¢tanga associated.” They are called Kir√¢tas P. 12, 19, P. 12, 26 and P. 13, L. 21, while at P. 12, L. 23 they are named Pulindas. [B√ºhler].

P. 12. L. 24. ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§É a Brahmin only in name. ‚Äú‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡•ã‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•á‡•§‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•à‡§ú‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä.

P. 13. L. 1. ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡§Øhaving set them, i. e., those who were made captive free? Kale reads ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø for which there is no authority in any manuscript, nor does the emendation make better sense. Since we have ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡•á immediately before ‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø, we had better take ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø in the sense of “release” after “dispossession of all their wealth.”

P. 13. L. 12. ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•á‡§∑‡•Å &c., for these punishments after death see ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£, ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§≤‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°, ‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø ‡•™‡•Æ and also ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á‡§Ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£, ‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø ‡•ß‡•®, also ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§ ‡•´‚Äì‡•®‡•¨.

P. 13. L. 13. ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§ü‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•à‡§É‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç “who were being chopped with sharp hatchets. [B√ºhler].

P. 13. L. 14. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•ç. Such release and return from the realms of Yama is a common incident in mythology and the later fables.

P. 13. L. 16. ‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§ÉBeing tended or watched Cf. P, 9. L. 14.

P. 13. L. 18. ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ Evidently the Brahmin who in L. 2. above is referred to as rescued from death at the hands of the Kir√¢tas.

‡§Ü‡§ó‡§Æ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞^(‡•¶)‚ÄúVeda and ≈öastras” [B√ºhler]. Evidently B√ºhler takes this as a Dvandva compound, but it might be taken as a Tatpurusha and ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ understood in its ordinary sense of ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§® ( principal ) or ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ( conclusion). Vide Amarako≈õa. III. 3. 186. ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§. Thus, the expression might mean “the conclusions arrived at in the different sciences or branches of learning.”

P. 14. L. 2. ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø " which is being worshipped by Siddhas and S√¢dhyas” [B√ºhler]. The Siddhas are a class of gods-‡§™‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§ö‡•ã ‡§ó‡•Å‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§É ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§É Amarako≈õa (I L. 11) ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É are demigods or attendants upon gods, ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö Amarako≈õa, I. 1. 10.

P. 14. L. 3. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ as if it were an opening made by destiny or fate.

P. 14. L. 4. ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç properly ‚Äòan edict of grant written on a copper-plate’. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø perform the ceremonies (prescribed) on that, considering (that they will procure) victory over fate’ [B√ºhler].

P. 14. L. 10. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® every one of them.

**P. 14. L. 16.**‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Øis a better reading than the‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡§§‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø.

P. 14. L. 17. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§π‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§ø ‚Äòwhilst R√¢jav√¢hana wardedoff all impediments orinterruptions’ (of the sacrifice by evil spirits etc.). [B√ºhler].

P. 14. L. 18. ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•á‡§π‡§Æ‡•çabode of merit.

P. 14. L. 24. ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä. Bhatta N√¢r√¢ya·πáa takes this best of demons as Namuchi (Vide Appendix ).

P. 14. L. 25. ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•áaugIn which the gods were routed.

P. 15. L. 7. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•Å ‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‚Äòmake me the rival of that (kingdom) i. e., marry me’ the kingdom being considered the first wife of the King [B√ºhler].

P. 15. L. 12. ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç (who accompanied him) for some distance. [B√ºhler].)

P. 15. L. 14. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‚ÄúUjjain.‚Äù ‡§â‡§™‡§∂‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø ‚ÄúAn open space near a village or town." [B√ºhler] Cf. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç…‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç-‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç Megh. I. 30.

P. 15. L. 16. ‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§ö‡•ã‡§§‡§æ‡§É It is impossible to render exactly the very common simile of the Sansk·πõit poets, by which the mind is compared to a tree and is said to throw out sprouts or shoots under the affection of joy. It may be translated by ‘his mind being moved or affected by great joy’ [B√ºhler].

P. 15. L. 19. ‡§∏‡§∞‡§≠‡§∏ &c. From ‡§∏‡§∞‡§≠‡§∏ to ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø must be taken as a compound qualifying ‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑ and the whole word as a Bahuvr√Æh√Æ.

P. 15. L. 21. ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ refers to ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§® though he was properly ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú, without a kingdom.

P. 16. L. 1. ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§Ø‡•ã.From the way in which ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§ is introduced to the reader ‘seated on a swing in the midst of damsels, there appears to be no visible sign of anxiety, unless it be on account of the disappearance of ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§®.

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1722348684Screenshot2024-07-30115049.png"/>

THIRD UCHCHHV√ÇSA.

P.16. L. 10. ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡§æ‡§∂‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø. * Whose mind was filled with hopes of (obtaining) liberation’ [B√ºhler]. But it would be better to consider this a lapse on the part of the author. Vide note to P. 2. L. 22. where this expression is discussed at some length.

P. 16. L. 12. “Something seems to have been left out in our Mss., as nothing has been said before regarding a royal camp” [B√ºhler]. May not the pronoun ‡§è‡§§‡§§‡•çbe taken as pointing with a finger towards a camp in the distance, since the context seems to suggest that Somadatta’s very words are quoted ?

P. 16. L. 14. ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ü‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É ‚Äòthe country of L√¢ta, the Larike of the ancients, corresponds nearly to Central Gujarat" (B√ºhler). According to Vincent A. Smith, it is Southern Gujar√¢t (P 425, Early History of India Ed. 1914). It is mentioned as one of the 18 Ma·πádalas or provinces in the Kum√¢rap√¢la Prabandha Chint√¢ma·πái P. 243, R√¢jya-bhakta Printing Press, Bombay, A. D. 1888 ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§® ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ü‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§É says Jayamangala.

P. 16. L. 16. ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø who scorned (Mattak√¢la’s) suit for (the hand of) his (V√Æraketu’s) daughter. ‡§™‡§æ‡§ü‡§≤‡•Ä a town which seems to have been situated somewhere near ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ.

P. 21. L. 1. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ Quality as a Magician.

P. 21. L. 2. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§ï Indicating various (buried)treasures.

P. 21. L. 3. ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ filled with treasure or coin.

‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡•á‡§® ‚ÄòBy Magic collyrium’ enabling the eyes to see through opaque substances [Wilson].

P. 21. L. 4. ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§∞ is derived from the Latin denarius and denotes a gold coin. According to K√¢ty√¢yana and B·πõihaspati, as quoted by Nandapa·πádita on Vish·πáu IV. 9, a Din√¢ra is equal in value to 42 K√¢rshika Pa·πáas. Din√¢ras were first coined in India by the Indo-Scythian Kings, Kanishka and his succes-sors [B√ºhler]. It may, however, be noted that the word ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§∞ is given by Amarasi·πÉha III. 3. 14. and is derived by Ksh√Ærasvamin as ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡•à‡§∞‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç. It is formed according to Bhattoji D√Ækshit under the Un√¢di S√ªtra ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã ‡§®‡•Å‡§ü‡•ç ‡§ö (427 U. S.). T√¢r√¢n√¢tha in his V√¢chaspatyam explains ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§∞ as ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§π‡•á‡§Æ‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§ï‡•à‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•á though he does not give a more definite reference to this Vish·πáugupta. It is clear, therefore, that the word was known to the author of the Un√¢di S√ªtr√¢s, Amarasi·πÉha and also to Vish·πáugupta.

It is also worthy of note that the author refers to the find of hidden treasure in the vicinity of the “sites of old towns,” implying thereby that there were even in his times relics of an earlier age.

P. 21. L. 5. ‡§ó‡•ã‡§£‡•Ä ‘a bag.’ Here the double bags are meant which the Vanj√¢ras and other traders use for conveying grain on their bullocks. [B√ºhler].

P. 21. L. 6. ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§£Pretending that it was other people’s property.
P. 21. L. 7. ‡§§‡§¶‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æwith their leader.
P. 21. L. 10. ‡§ó‡•Ç‡§¢‡§µ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø living in cognito.
P. 21. L. 17. ‡§≤‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§¨‡§æ‡§£ = ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§ß‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ the flower god or the god of love. Cf. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï in the next line.
P. 21. L. 18. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® Nominal verb from ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï ‘an arrow.’
P. 22. L. 3. ‡§∞‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø^(‡•¶) on account of the confidence produced by privacy.
P. 22. L. 7.‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‚Äî ‚ÄòHim√¢laya, the abode of Kubera.’ (B√ºhler). ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú is a name of Kubera and his residence is Kail√¢sa and not Him√¢laya. Mark Collins refers to this mention as ‘purely mythical’ and one in which “the border line between real and mythical or fabulous geography is wholly disregarded” (P. 12. Geographical Data of the Da≈õak. ).
P. 22. L. 10. ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ Enamoured or charmed with your handsome appearance.
Note that ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç should properly have formed part of the compound ‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç.
P. 22. L. 11. ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‚Äònot caring (if he commits) [B√ºhler].
P. 22. L. 15. ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§Ø having possessed. ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∂‡•É‡§ô‡•ç‡§ñ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã ’ who chained or captivated by the hope of obtaining) that treasure of a form i. e., that beautiful damsel.’
P. 22. L. 18. ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§® by a sage or seer.
P. 23. L. 1. ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡§®‡•á In a secluded apartment.
P. 23. L. 4. ‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¢‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø ‚Äúto me who am rich in personal charms and in nobility of birth or descent."

P. 23. L. 8. ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡§•‡§É note the use of ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç when in the sentence immediately preceding ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ is addressed as ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç. In the succeeding the succeeding sentence he is again addressed as ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç.
P. 23. L. 20. ‡§®‡§ó‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç spread or known all over the town.
‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§®‡•ç can be defended by the Paribhasha ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•á‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç which though rejected by N√¢goji, is admitted by Bhattoji, Siddh. II P. 112. Compare also the Pet. Dict. under ‡§à‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç+‡§™‡§∞‡§ø where examples of the Parasmaipada from the Mah√¢bh√¢rata and the Pur√¢·πáas are given [B√ºhler].
P. 24. L. 1. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§£‡•á Parab also reads ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§£‡•á which though suggestive of impropriety gives a more intelligible meaning. Wilson seems to have toned down the expression to ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§®‡•á, as he has done. wherever he found a trace of indecency.
P. 24. L. 2. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§®‡•ç must be taken here in the sense of “Killed.” ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äòpugilistic encounter, personal encounter’ [B√ºhler]. ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡§≠‡§∏‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡§Æ‡•çthrown into disorder in the heat of the wrestling or single combat.
P. 24. L. 15. ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à i. e., to Pushpodbhava.
P. 24. L. 19. ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞ ‘best of Brahmins’ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§ü‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç ‘proclaiming’ (that R√¢jav√¢hana the best of Brahmins was skilled in all arts). For a reason for such a feint, See P. 27. L. 4-7.
**P. 24. L. 20.**‡§Ö‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç. Parab and Kale read ‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç which is better, since ‡§Ö‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§® would mean’ anointing’ and not bathing."

**
FIFTH UCHCHHV√ÄSA.**

**
_____________**

P. 25. L. 1. ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§®‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡§®^(‡•¶) ‚Äú who was the leader of thearmy of the god having the fish on his banner i. e., the god of love."

‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø. ‚ÄúThe snakes are said to feed on air and are called ‡§™‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§® or ‡§™‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§®‡•ç (compare the Pet. Dict. Sub v. v.) Hence the South wind may be called the leavings of the snakes of the Malaya hills." [B√ºhler].
P. 25. L. 2. ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§£’Thinner,’ because the serpents had had their feed before it blew blew away from the Malaya hills.
‡§ß‡•Ç‡§§‡§π‡§∞‡§ø^(‡•¶) Parab and Kale read ya for ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§§, which is a better reading, since it assigns a reason for the following epithet ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§æ.
P. 25. L. 3. ‡§∏‡§π‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø “Making the air noisy with the sweet sounds of the bees and of the koils whose throats were made tuneful by tasting the sap of the young sprouts of the Mango trees.‚Äù [B√ºhler].
P. 25. L. 10. ‡§ö‡•Ç‡§§‡§™‡•ã‡§§‡§ï gada small or young Mango tree.
P. 25. L. 11. ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø “consisting of various kinds such as sandal, flowers, rice mixed with saffron, minium and ambra " [B√ºhler].
P. 25. L. 15. ‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§≤‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•Å Ras√¢la is a name of various trees, but may be understood here of the Mango which blossoms in spring [Wilson.]
P. 25. L. 16. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∞^(‡•¶) ‚Äì‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∞ is blue lotus, ‡§ï‡§π‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§∞ is white lotus, ‡§ï‡•à‡§∞‡§µ also a species of white lotus, ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ is also a blue lotus.

P. 25. L. 20. ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡•Ç‡§§ literally ‚Äúinvoked by many,“a name of Indra. [B√ºhler].
P. 25. L. 21. Construe ‡§Ø‡§æ with ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§µ ‡§∞‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú.
P. 25. L. 25. ‡§ú‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡§• see above, note on P. 2. L. 19. [B√ºhler]:
Translate “and she shone as if created by Cupid who, who, fondly fondly longing after Rati, and desiring to make a statue of her, framed some female figure, produced its feet from the beauty of the autumnal lotus growing in his pleasure garden” &c. [B√ºhler]. Cf. L. 2-10 P. 2 for a similar description.
P. 26. L. 4. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§¨‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§Æ‡•ç literally ‘which made the Bimba fruit an imitation’ or more freely, which surpassed the Bimba-fruit. [B√ºhler].
**P. 26. L. 14.**‡§ò‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® literally “according to the analogy of the wood-borer’s writing, i. e., accidentally.” When the insect called Ghu·πáa, makes, holes in the wood, they occasionally resemble letters. But, of course, that happens accidentally. Compare ≈öi≈õup√¢lavadha III. 58. [B√ºhler].
P. 26. L. 18. ‡§∞‡•á‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç^(‡•¶)Wilson reads ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§ which is better. Does ‡§∞‡•á‡§ö‡§ø‡§§ here mean curved as explained by Pa·∏ç. at P. 53. L7?. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø^(‡•¶‚Äò)Whose beauty captivated herjust as the snare captures the deer [B√ºhler]. She was herself the deer and the beauty of R√¢jav√¢hana was the snare (‡§Ü‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø) to her.
P.26. L. 19. ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç^(‡•¶) ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ state of mind and ‡§∞‡§∏ sentiment or emotion. See below P. 53. L. 2.

P. 26. L. 21. Wilson and Parab read ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø which is decidedly a better reading than the old one‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø.
P. 27. L. 12. ‡§∂‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‚Äòat the time when (the effects of) the ascetic’s curse ceases. See P. 37 LL. 11-14. [B√ºhler].
P. 27. L. 25. ‡§®‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç “a professed student” i. e., such a one who after completing the study of the Veda stays with his teacher and becomes an ascetic, without having passed through the “Grihasth√¢≈õrama” [B√ºhler].
P. 28. L. 7. ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‚ÄîPower to remember the incidents of a previous birth. This sort of ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æis a favourite device of this author and is taken advantage of in bringing about love marriages. For similar instances, see Ratnaprabh√¢ Lambaka, Taranga IX, verses 154-156 and also ≈öaktiya≈õo Lambaka, Taranga IX v. 56, Kath√¢saritsag√¢ra.
For a wife in a previous birth, see the same Lambaka and Taranga, verse 233.
P. 28. L. 20. Note the double meaning of ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§π‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï as 1st “the best of swans” and 2ndly “an ornament to the family of ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§π‡§Ç‡§∏’ the father of the hero ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§®.
P. 28. L. 22. ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ωo also in the ≈ö√¢kuntala, the heroine when called away by Gautam√Æ in the 3rd Act addresses the bower of creepers in which she was resting.
‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡§æ Cf. ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ö‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä &c., ≈ö√¢kuntala Act II. v. 13.
P. 29. L. 1. ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§≤‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ the dark half of the month. [B√ºhler]

** P. 29. L. 2.** ‡§∞‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡•áIn her private apartment.

P. 29. LL. 1-5. For these remedies against the ‘fire of love’ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§≤ Compare ≈ö√¢kuntala Act III.
P. 29. L. 13. ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á. For a similar sentiment, compare ‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡•Ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§π‡§∞‡§ï‡•ã‡§™‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡§á‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•å & ‡§§‡§µ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§∂‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§§‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§É &c, ≈ö√¢kuntala Act III.
P. 29. L. 13. ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞; &c. The origin and the attributes of this submarine fire are thus given in the Mah√¢bh√¢rata :‚Äî‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§§ ‡§î‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡•á‡•§ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú ‡§∏ ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§™ ‡§â‡§™‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡•ã‡§¶‡§ß‡•å‡•• ‡•®‡•ß ‡•• ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§¨‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ã‡§Æ‡§π‡•ã‡§¶‡§ß‡•á‡§É‡•• ‡•®‡•® ‡•• √Çdiparva, Chap. 196. v. 18 ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø Compare ≈ö√¢kuntala, ≈öloka 117. Note the paronomasia involved in the word ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞ which means the moon and is in that sense brother to Lakshm√Æ (‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§æ).

P. 29. L. 24. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç Ito a state of being remembered i. e., dead.

** P. 30. L. 4.**‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç &c. Like a creeper to be sought after, coming to the root of the tree.

** P. 30. L. 5.** ‡§®‡§ø‡§ü‡§ø‡§≤‡§§‡§ü^(‡•¶)&c., whose clasped palms shining like the bud of a lotus formed an ornament to the edge of her forehead.
P. 30. L. 10. ‡§â‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§§‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§´‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç &c., Compare ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•Å‡§≤‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§´‡§≤‡•á ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§É Raghu. I. 3.

** P. 30. L. 14.** metre √Çry√¢‚Äî‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•É‡§¶‡•Å‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç as tender (as thy body is soft) [B√ºhler].

** P. 3 L. 18.** ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•Ä‡§µ‡§® ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø. B√ºhler had the following note on this:-“My conjecture ‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Éinstead of the senseless ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ or ‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Éof the Mss. is suggested by the expression ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§≠‡§µ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ‡•á P. 25 L. 12.” We shouldprefer to read ‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§É, 1st, because we have in line 20. P. 28. above, ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡•á ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§° ‡§è‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡§Æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•á and 2ndly, we have immediately in the following sentence ‡§Ö‡§™‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç.It is clear, therefore, that she stole his heart when she departed. Moreover, we have gravedoubts as to the propriety of ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡•áas B√ºhler’s reading would seem to suggest.
**P. 31. L. 5.**‡§≤‡§≤‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø. If this reading is correct, the meaning must be that R√¢jav√¢hana, on seeing the trees from which Avantisundari had plucked
flowers, the place where she had worshipped, the gravel bearing the imprint of her feet and her flower-couch, constantly called to mind that these things were ‘residues’ produced by her, or “mementoes of her” and thereby increased his passion, ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§Æ‡•ç is ‚Äúany thing which has been used by another person and then abandoned, marked with the signs. of having been used.” [B√ºhler].
P. 31. L. 17. ‡§∏‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø Compare Pa√±chatantra II ≈öloka 42; IV ≈öloka 107. [B√ºhler]. also ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§£‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡•Ç‡§ÉRaghu. II. 58.
P. 32. L. 2. ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞ evidently refers to ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§®.
‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ^(‡•¶) is very plausibly understood by Kale in the sense of magic.
‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‚Äì‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ‚Äì‡§∏‡§π‡§ú‡§∏‡•å‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‚Äì‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§Ç ‚ÄúWho knew deception, studied or pretended love and natural or spontaneous tenderness.” Or the expression might mean “who knew the tenderness born of love, caused by separation.” The latter seems to suit better, since that would show that ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞ could realise the feelings of ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§®

P. 32. L. 7. ‡§∞‡§∏‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§É,At page 27. L. 8. we have ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏ and here the same pair in a reverse order, ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§ó‡§§‡§ø may mean the usual mode or direction ( ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ) ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø progress or movement of the sentiment and (‡§∞‡§∏) state of mind (‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ). Godbole explains ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§ó‡§§‡§Ø‡§É as‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§É.

P. 32. L. 11. ‡§ï‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç’the the interior apartments’ [B√ºhler]. The expression properly means another apartment (‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§ï‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ).

P. 32. L. 14. ‡§™‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø. “The reading adopted is that of Professor T√¢r√¢n√¢th Tarkav√¢chaspati’s edition which gives a better sense than that of the Mss. It may be translated “and while he together with his attendants was violently whirling brushes of peacock’s feathers in circles’ [B√ºhler]. The following gloss on the word ‡§™‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ occurring in verse 48 of the Mallik√¢ M√¢ruta will be found interesting :‚Äî‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§ï‡§∞‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ï‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡•ã‡§≠‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•à‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§ñ‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§¶‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§≤‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•á‡§∑‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§π‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§â‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§ú‡•ã‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§µ‡•á ‡§ú‡§≤‡•á‡•§ ‡§¨‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§™‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§≤‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Ω‡§®‡§ø‡§≤‡•á‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§°‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§≤‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§.

P. 32. L. 16. ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§Éwhich waved before the spacious royal palace the light (issuing from) rows of gems (in their hoods). The supposition is that cobras have a hidden gem in their hoods, which is visible only when they spread out their hoods.

P. 32. L. 18. ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äúwho was astonished at this great (event). [B√ºhler]. We doubt the accuracy of this explanation, since ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç which is an adjective cannot be used as a substantive. Instead of leaning upon a broken reed, it would be much better to concede at once that the author of the P√ªrvap√Æthik√¢ did not understand the correct use of ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç What the author evidently meant to convey was the intense astonishment of the King and‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç is meant to qualify ‡§Ü‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø.
P. 32. L. 23. ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§ú‡§®‡§ï‡§Æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç a collyrium which is supposed to have the power of stupefying the spectators or onlookers. See the quotation under ‡§™‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ above P. 32. L. 14. ante.
P. 33. L. 3. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§É men conjured up by magic.
P. 33. L. 4. ‡§ó‡•Ç‡§¢‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ By skill in devising secret means.
** P. 33. L. 6.** ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§Ø Compare ‡§Ü‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ II, 3, 7, 9 and II 4, 9, 1 and the dramas. [B√ºhler].
P. 33. L. 7. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç the apartment of the Princess. R√¢jav√¢hana had already got access to the same, vide L. 4. above.
P. 33. L. 10. ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç Compare Vedanta S√¢ra.
P. 15 (Calc. Ed). But see also below notes on P. 34. L. 1. and P. 38. L. 1. [B√ºhler].

It is interesting to compare V√¢tsy√¢yana’s K√¢mas√ªtra in this connection. Says V√¢tsy√¢yana. “‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡§®‡§É‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∞‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç”.
The following extract from Bhatta N√¢r√¢ya·πáa’s P√ªrv√¢p√Æthik√¢ gives a better explanation of the narration referred to ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§ó‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§®‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§

                            End of the P√ªrvap√Æthik√¢.

DA≈öAKUMARA-CHARITAM.

UCHCHHV√ÇSA 1.

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1722320759Screenshot2024-07-30115049.png"/>

P. 34. L. 1. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ[ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç] ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§π ‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ö ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§®‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡§è‡§µ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø [ P. 38 L. 1] ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø Bh√ª.Pa·∏ç.explains ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç by ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É‡•§ but wrongly. The use of Pur√¢nic tales for purposes similar to those of R√¢jav√¢hana, seems to have been very frequent. Compare, e. g., below, P. 44. L. 3. [ B√ºhler ].
P. 34. L. 6. ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡•§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§£‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§∑‡§£‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É‡•§ ‡§¶‡§∂‡§®‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§¶‡§ì‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§É‡•§ …….‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§ú‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§§‡§ü‡•ã‡§™‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∞‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É‡•• Pa·∏ç. Regarding the use of ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§∑‡§£‡§Ωee above, note to P. 31. L. 5. and translate ‘which has been kissed or touched,’ R√¢jav√¢hana is here compared to Vish·πáu, as stated in the Bh√ªsha·πá√¢. ‡§è‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§£‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•å‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§∂‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡•á ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§ø‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡•É‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§Æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ú ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡•É‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
P. 34. L. 7. ‡§ö‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç can only be explained as the infinitive of the causal, but there is obviously no need of using the causal at all.
