** P. 137. L. 10** (2) ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§ß‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡•à‡§ÉBy contriving to send (them) into the jaws of tigers, &c., after encouraging (men) to hunt them.

(3) ‡§á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ï‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡•á‡§® etc. By aggravating hunger and thirst, so much so as to threaten impen ding death (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É) after dragging people over long distances to slake their thirst with the water of a desired well.

** P. 137. L. 11.** (4).‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•É‡§£‡§ó‡•Å‡§¢&c. By running over uneven paths, causing falls over ups (‡§§‡§ü) and downs (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§∞) covered and hidden under grass and bushes.

** P. 137. L. 12. (5).**‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ø‡§É&c., By extracting thorns with knives the points of which were dipped in poison.

** P. 137. L. 13. (6).**‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞ &c. By killing at pleasure those who were alone and separated from their followers, who were dispersed in all directions.

(7). ‡§Æ‡•É‡§ó‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•à‡§É&c., By the darting of arrows which seemingly missed to hit the bodies of deer.

** P. 137. L. 14. (8)** ‡§∏‡§™‡§£‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ç&c., By pushing down unobserved by others, after (making them) climb with a wager the summits of mountains difficult of ascent.

** P. 137. L. 15. (9).** ‡§Ü‡§ü‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ &c., By surrounding or capturing small parties of soldiers in forests, as if the raid were made by wild tribes.

** P. 137. L. 16. (10)**. ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§ &c. By forcibly driving people into crowds assembled for fairs or fights of birds or gambling-booths

** (11)**. ‡§á‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç &c., By causing the assassination of others.

** P. 137. L. 17. (12).** ‡§ó‡•Ç‡§¢‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡•Ä‡§ï‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É&c., By attempts upon others (‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•à‡§É) purporting to shield them from obloquy, having publicly obtained unpleasant disclosures and having communicated the same to witnesses, after having themselves secretly caused mischief or injury.

** P. 137. L. 18. (13).**‡§™‡§∞‡§ï‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å &c., Having introduced lewd persons to the wives of others under the guise of friends and having killed either the husbands or both and having brought these acts of violence to notice.

P. 137. L. 19. (14). ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç&c., By secret murders of persons decoyed by women soliciting in streets (‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä) to assignations after having previously concealed themselves. The Ah·∏ç. quotes from the Vaijayanti the following couplet. ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§We have omitted the last two lines which are illegible. ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§®‡§Ç is explained as ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á.

P. 137. L. 20. (15). ‡§â‡§™‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡•ã‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø&c., By murders committed under the pretextof hindrances, having induced (men) to entercaves, or to excavatetreasure-troves or to attain success in incantations.

P. 137. L. 21. (16). ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ó‡§ú‡§æ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ã‡§π‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø&c. By causing men to return at risk to their them ride elephants in rut.

** P. 137. L. 22. (17).**‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§Ç&c., By wagers aboutthe irregular movement of wicked elephants along acentral circle or ring specially marked.

** P. 138. L. 1. (18).**‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•áBy throwing the blame upon the opposite party, after having secretly killed litigants quarrelling for inheritance.

** P. 138. L. 2. (19).**‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•Å‡§∞&c., After having secretly killed the ill-behaved among feudatories, citizens and among the rural population, proclaiming the names of their enemies.

P. 138. L. 3. (20). ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§É&c., By bringing on consumption, after having brought about incessant intercourse with young women. In a quotation from R√¢javallabha, a ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æin the sense of a young woman is distinguished from ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§æand ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§¢‡§æ on the one hand, and ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æon the other.

** (21).**‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡§∞‡§£&c., By skill in poisoning clothes, ornaments, flowers and ointments.

** P. 138. L. 4. (22).**‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•á‡§®&c., By aggravating bodily disorders under the guise of medical treatment.

** P. 138. L. 5.**‡§§‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§∞‡§∏¬∞Poisoners and others.

** P. 138. L. 7.**‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç is used of the King here Cf. below 11. 19 and 23 (Peterson). Vanav√¢s√Æ was one of the seats of the Kadamba Kings in the sixth and seventh centuries and is the modern Vanav√¢s√Æ in North Kanara (Fleet’s Dynasties of Kan. Districts Bom. Gazetteer Vol. I. Pt. 2. PP. 285, 291 and note 1 on pp. 278-279). The Mah√¢bh√¢rata mentions‡§µ‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§É and from the context these appear to be the inhabitants of Vanav√¢s√Æ. The passage names all the peoples of the South as under:‚Äî‡§Ö‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•á ‡§ú‡§®‡§™‡§¶‡§æ ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§æ ‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§≠‡•§ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§°‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•á‡§∞‡§≤‡§æ‡§É‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§µ‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§ü‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡§ï‡§æ‡§É&c. Bh√Æshma Parva IX 58-59. Jayama·πÖgala in his commentary on the ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ says ‡§ï‡•ã‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§£‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§£ ‡§µ‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§ÉThe Pa·∏ç. and Ah·∏ç. both explain ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É as ‡§µ‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§É but cite no authority. Wilson reads. ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç The text adopted by us seems to be correct, since it is supported by the commentaries as well as by our Southern Ms.

** P. 138. L. 9.**‡§Ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ÉThe King of the A≈õmakas. The A≈õmakas, though placed by Var√¢hamihira in the North-West (Br. S. XIV 22) are mentioned along with ‡§Ü‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞ and ‡§ã‡§∑‡•Ä‡§ïin XVI. II. They are included by Mr. C. V. Vaidya amongst people inhabiting Hindustan proper or North India (Epic India Note II. P. 482). Nundolal Dey who has supplied the map prefixed to R√¢dhakumud Mukerji’s Fundamental Unity of India has shown their country to the West of Janasth√¢na and south of Devagiri. ‘‘A tribe of A≈õmakas or

Assakas was settled at the time when the Suttanip√¢ta was composed on the banks of the God√¢vari. This is no doubt the same tribe whose name appears in inscriptions at Ajant√¢ of about the sixth century A.D. and they therefore probably occupied land near the sources of this river in the Western Deccan, South of Berar.” (Mark Collins Geog. Data p. 42)..

**P. 138. L. 10.**‡§Ö‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§øagainst the enemy.

P. 138. L. 11. ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§§‡•ç encamped. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§≤‡§™‡§§‡•á‡§É‚ÄîKuntala ‘‘was the country between the Bh√Æm√¢ and Vedavat√Æ, bounded on the West by the Ghats, including Shimoga, Chitaldroog, Bellary, Dh√¢rw√¢r and Bijapur and adjacent parts (V. Smith’s Early History P. 148).

‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ü‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§®‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç Pa·∏ç.

P. 138. L. 15. ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•É‡§∂‡§§‡§ø originally means ’touches., Here the sense is ‘defiles.’

P. 138. L. 16. ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∞‡§≤‡•á‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç"The name (Muralas) occurs in an inscription found at Bhera Ghat on the Narmad√¢ but among others equally unknown or of such divergent parts that we derive no hint as to the location of this tribe. In the Raghu, a river Mural√¢ or Marul√¢ is mentioned in connection with the country of the Keralas and it is possible that the Keralas of this passage are the same as Da·πá·∏çin’s Mural√¢s. But to identify these with the Keralas of the extreme south is hardly warranted by the data of his romance.‚Äù (Mark Collins Geog. Data of Da≈õak. P. 43). Nundolal Dey gives Narmad√¢ as another name for Mural√¢. The Trik√¢nda≈õesha gives Marundal√¢ (‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§≤‡§æ) as a synonym of Mural√¢ but this does not
[46 D. K.]

help us to locate that river. Dr. S. K. Belwalkar in his Marathi translation of Bhavabh√ªti’s UttaraR√¢macharitam conjectures that the Mural√¢ must have been a tributary of the God√¢vari near Pa√±chavati. (see 3-5 P. 132). See however extract from K√¢vyaM√Æm√¢ms√¢ for this name in our Note on ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡•çOn the next page.

P. 138. L. 17. ‡§ã‡§∑‡•Ä‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•çThe reading of the old edition was ‡§ã‡§ö‡•Ä‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•çbut since our Southern Ms. and B. and C. cited inthe old edition have ‡§ã‡§∑‡•Ä‡§ï¬∞ for ‡§ã‡§ö‡•Ä‡§ï, and the name ‡§ã‡§∑‡§ø‡§ïis found in the R√¢m√¢ya·πáa (IV. 41)and the Mah√¢bh√¢rata (Bh√Æshma Parva, Chap. IX, v64) and also theB·πõihat-Sa·πÉhit√¢ (XIV. 14), wehave preferred‡§ã‡§∑‡•Ä‡§ï as the more satisfactory reading.

As regards the position of the Rsh√Ækas, we find these people placed immediately before Vidarbhas in the description of Jambudv√Æpa, though they are also mentioned along with the K√¢mbojas in the North (Bh√Æshma Parva, XXV, 26). They are more definitely mentioned in the R√¢m√¢yana in the following line: ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§®‡•É‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§µ ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡§ø‡•§ The countries named by Sugr√Æva in the context before and after Rsh√Æka seem to point to some order in the enumerati on.The B·πõihat-Sa·πÉhita mentions the Rsh√Ækas among Southern peoples (XIV. 14) and Dravidas, Videhas, √Çndhras, √Ç≈õmakas, Bh√¢s√¢puras and Konkanas are all strung together in one verse in XVI. II.

Gorresio’s reading ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç for ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç seems to be wrong, since it neither gives good meaning nor suitsthe context.There is the further difficulty of taking M√¢hi≈üik√Æ as M√¢hismat√Æ and to reconcile the interpretation when Avanti is mentioned in the context immediately before Vidarbha.

The Bombay recension of the R√¢m√¢ya·πáa no doubt gives ‡§ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ïas another reading for ‡§ã‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï and it would be risky to identify the Rsh√Ækas with the Rattis on the slender authority of an alternative reading unsupported by any collateral evidence.

‡§ï‡•ã‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§£‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•çKonka·πáa is here rightly taken by Mark Collins to stand for for the sea-coast country which ‘‘began about Chaul or Chemval in the Kolaba District twenty miles north of Bombay and appears to have extended over the whole of Kolaba and Thana.‚Äù

‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡§Æ‡•ç The other readings here are hard to make out. Mark Collins refers to the named ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ïbeing found in the Bh√Æshma Parva Ch. IX but the word there is‡§∂‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§É. Mr. Vaidya’s list of countries does not give the name. The name ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø has not yet been traced by any one. ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§ø‡§ïis found in the B·πõihat-Sa·πÉhit√¢(‡§Ö‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•å‡§ú‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•áXI. 56.) but there is nothing to guide us in locating this tribe. The only satisfactory reading is ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§Øwhich is mentioned in the following verse ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§ü‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ü‡§µ‡§ø ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ç‡§ü‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•ã‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡•ã‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§™‡§ú‡§ü‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡•§ B·πõihat-Sa·πÉhit√¢, XIV. 13. N√¢sikya is the present N√¢sik on the God√¢vari. The following extract from the ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æmentions all these countries except ‡§ã‡§∑‡•Ä‡§ï ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§§‡•ã‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§™‡§•‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§≤ x x x ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∞‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï x x x ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§£……‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ú‡§®‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§É‡•§ See P. 93.

P. 138. L. 19. ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•çengaged.

P. 138. L. 20. ‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø We must take ‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ compound. “We will divide between ourselves the treasure and the transport.” See ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§®‡§Æ‡§µ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç in L. 24 below where ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç must be taken in the sense of ‘scattered or fleeing here and there in the tumult of the battle.’

** P. 138. L. 21.** ‡§ï‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§ï‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç Wilson notices the reading ‡§ï‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§ï‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§™‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç, taking ‡§™‡§≤ in the sense of a ’ measure of weight. Probably saffron-coloured goldinterlaced woollen garments, that is, shawls are meant.

** P. 138. L. 22.** ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§Pa·∏ç.

P. 138. L. 24. ‡§®‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç Fell a prey on account of his hatred of political science. To fall a prey is a common expression, eg., ‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§£‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•å Raghu XII II.

P. 139. L. 6. ‡§Æ‡•å‡§≤‡•à‡§Éhereditary ministers.

P. 139. L. 13. ‡§®‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§ú‡§ô‡•ç‡§öThe man’s name. For the awkward way in which it is introduced, doubtless from the original narratives which Da·πá·∏çin is using, compare the similar case above, P. 100. L. 21. [Peterson] ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§ØHaving deposited or left in custody.

P. 139. L. 16. ‡§ò‡•ã‡§∑ ‡§Ü‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∂‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡•§ ‡§ò‡•ã‡§∑ ‡§Ü‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡§ÉPa·∏ç.

P. 139. L. 17. ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç Bad road.

P. 139. L. 20. ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§É Bh√ª. “What like is his mother by birth or caste?” Wilson.

P. 139. L. 23. ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•áAnother instance of the irregular use of the refuplicated Perfect with the 1st Person. One learned Pandit defends this as ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡§É ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ü‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•á.

**P. 140. L. 1.**‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§®‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø Having rooted out by nothing else than policy A≈õmakendra who prided himself upon his policy. The Pa·∏ç. reads ‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§®‡§Ø‡•á‡§® the last word being explained as ‡§™‡§æ‡§∑‡§æ‡§£‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§®‡•á‡§® which certainly does not make better sense than the reading in our text.. The author is playing upon the word‡§®‡§Ø.

**P. 140. L. 4.**‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡•Ä‡§∑‡•Å‡§®‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø It seems that the hunter aimed three arrows in succession at the two deer but the latter succeeded in out-running the range of each.

**P. 140. L. 5.**‡§∏‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§®‡•á [Pan V. 4. 61.] ‡§∏‡§™‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ñ‡§∂‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡•§‡§∏‡§™‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ñ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É‡•§ Sid. Kau. “One pierced the animal to the feathered part, the other passed quite through and left the feathers behind; hence one is said to be ‡§∏‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§É, and the other ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§É.” [Wilson].

P. 140. L. 6. ‡§Ö‡§™‡§≤‡•ã‡§Æ ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Æ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§Æ ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡§É Pa·∏ç. the lungs.

P. 140. L. 7. ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•§ ‘‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•ã‡§∑‡§£‡•á’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§°‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡•§[Pa·πá.V. 44 62. ] ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§π‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§π‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§°‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç Sid. Kau. Having cut up the body ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø.‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•§ ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§≤‡•á ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ [‡§∂‡•Ç‡§≤‡•á‡§® ] ‡§™‡§æ‡§ö‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É‡•§ ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§ï‡•á ( V. 4. 64). ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§°‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡•§

P. 140. L. 8. ‡§Ö‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§∑‡§Æ‡•çmust be taken in the sense of ‘‘satisfied” a very unusual sense. Wilson’s reading ‡§Ö‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡•çis certainly the best, though it is unsupported by the Mss. The Pa·∏ç. reads ‡§Ö‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡•çwhich it explains as ‡§Ö‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç, but it may be noted that the form ‡§Ö‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡•ç is itself very irregular.

**P. 140. L. 9.**‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ÄMahe≈õvara on the right bank of the Narmad√¢ forty miles to the South of Indore. It was the capital of Haihaya or Anupade≈õa, the Kingdom of the myriad-handed K√¢rtav√Æry√¢rjuna of the Pur√¢ns.

** P. 140. L. 15.**‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ørefers to prince Bh√¢skaravarm√¢.

** P. 140. L. 18.**‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Æ‡•ç scorned your proposal.

** P. 140. L. 20.** ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§É‡•§ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•ã ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡§É‡•§ Pa·∏ç. akind of very strong poison. ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•§

** P. 140. L. 22.** ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ Something like ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç or some words to that effect are wanting here.

** P. 141 L. 3.** ‡§ï‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•å Dressed in the garb of ascetics.

** P. 141. L. 7.**‡§µ‡•à‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É solitude.

** P. 141. L. 11.**‡§â‡§™‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•áWill take place or occur.

** P. 141. L. 12.**‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•çPa·∏ç.

** P. 141. L. 15.** ‡§â‡§™‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§™‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç Pa·∏ç.

** P. 141. L. 18.** ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡•§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§É‡•§

** P. 141. L. 22.** ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§§‡•á‡§∏‡•à ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡•§ Pa·∏ç. ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É refers to ‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä and hence ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡•Ä must be taken to mean that the vision foretold Ma√±juv√¢din√Æ’s marriage.

** P. 142. L. 2.**‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡•ç‡§¶‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É to be put under restraint or confined by me.

‡§Æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó&c. With my courage consumed by the love-stricken glance of ‡§Æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä. ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§π‡•Ç‡§Ø Ah·∏ç.

** P. 142. L. 4.** ‡§Ö‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ÉProclaimed as short-lived.

** P. 142. L. 6.** ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡•à‡§É‡•§ ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•à‡§ú‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡•§ Pa·∏ç.

** P. 142. L. 7.**‡§Æ‡§†‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§†‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§†‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡•§ Pa·∏ç. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§É"Clothes” [Wilson] ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡•§ ‘‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§¶‡•á‡§Ω‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•á‡§Ω‡§∂‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§£‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•á’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•à‡§ú‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡•§The Practical Sk. Dict. takes this word to mean ‘wealth, money, property’ in this context. We would go a little further than Wilson and take ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æin the sense of “paraphernalia” and not merely clothes, since ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§¶which is given as a synonym of ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æincludes as applied to a King not only all the emblems of royalty but even the usual accompaniments of reg√°l splendour, such as elephants, horses, chariots, &c.

** P. 142. L. 9.**‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡§™‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•á about the time when sun-shine had become red. We have a parallel expression in ≈öi≈õup√¢la-vadha IX. 7, where the hour of dusk is described as:‚Äî‡§µ‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ ‡§≠‡•É‡§∂‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§É Si. IX. 7.

** P. 142. L. 10.** ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§∏after having finished or gone through. ‡§ú‡§®‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä‡§®‡§ø‡•§ Wilson notices ‡§ú‡§®‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ã‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä‡§®‡§ø as the reading of his Mss. B. and D. The word‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§® seems almost redundant, but since all the Mss. including M. have that reading, we have retained it. Wilson translates the expression as ‚Äúactions or performances suited to the knowledge or taste of an assemblage of people.” The reading adopted by him in his edition viz., ‡§ú‡§®‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§Ø‡•Ä‡§ó‡•Ä does not make better sense, nor is it supported by the other Mss.

‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø the reading of A instead of ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø is certainly preferable, for the sounds made by birds and beasts are usually imitated and not their “weeping.‚Äù ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ö‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡•§ Pa·∏ç. This appears. to mean walking on two hands resting on the ground and with the feet held aloft in the air.

‡§ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡•Å‡§É‡•§ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§É‡•§ Pa·∏ç. ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§æ‡§§‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§µ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§®‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§§‡§ï‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ö‡•§ Ibid. ‡§µ‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§≤‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§™‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§®‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡•§ Pa·∏ç.

** P. 142. L. 12.**‡§Ü‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É Pa·∏ç. ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§É Ah·∏ç.

** P.142.L.13.**‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§£‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§∞‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§™‡§æ‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§É‡•§ Pa·∏ç. ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§∂‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡§∞‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§∂‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡§∞‡•å ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡§É‡•§ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É‡•§

** P. 142. L. 15.**‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ Pa·∏ç. ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§≠‡§ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•§ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•å‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ü‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§≠‡§ü‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§≠‡§ü‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ß‡§É‡•§ ‡§™‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ Pa·∏ç. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•Ä‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§É ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§≤‡•ã‡§™‡§É‡•§ Ah·∏ç. [Pan.V. 4, 51]. Making him insensible.

** P. 142 L. 18.** ‡§®‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§®‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§ &c. In which my footprints were hardly visible on account of N√¢l√Æjangha having levelled the sand.

** P. 142. L. 20.**‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç, On account of the bricks having been picked out.

‡§≤‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ &c.Having leapt over the moat and the ditch. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§ÉHaving doffed my former disguise.

** P. 143. L. 1.** ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§∞‡§µ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§™‡§ÉPa·∏ç.

** P. 143. L. 2.** ‡§≠‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§≤ &c.The outer entrance to which was covered by a large stone, placed for support, and the sides of which were chopped off, ‡§ó‡§≤‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á while the hour of midnight was passing. This seems to refer to ‡§ò‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞or time-measure, in which the water placed in a jar drops away through a hole at the bottom,

** P. 143. L. 4.** ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§µ‡§∞a eunuch or an attendant in women’s apartments,

** P. 143. L. 5.** ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ Having caused the funeral pyre to be lighted.

** P. 143. L. 8.** ‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§µ‡•à‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç The absence of any one in the interior having been ascertained by search.

** P. 143. L. 11.** ‡§≤‡•ã‡§π‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡•Ä‡§†‡§Æ‡•ç The iron pedestal. ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§∏‡§≤‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§≤‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§É‡•§ Pa·∏ç. Vide ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§¨‡§≤‡•á [ Pa·πá. V. 2. 98] where the Sid. Kau. explains the word by a ‡§¨‡§≤‡§µ‡§§‡§ø. ‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•É‡§§‡•à‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç. One side of which was supported by (my) both hands. ‡§è‡§ï‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø Having placed it on one side. ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç as before. Rather an unusual form, from ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ and ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ.

** P. 143. L. 14.** ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§ÉEvidently ‡§™‡•å‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§É mentioned in L. 7.

** P. 143. L. 17.**‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ÉOne whose maternal side is not weak.

‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡§ü‡§æ ‡§ò‡§ü‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§™‡§ü‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§ï‡•ã‡§ü‡§ø‡§∞‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡•§ ‡§ò‡§ü‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡•§ ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡§≤‡§§‡§æ‡•§ Pa·∏ç. The whole compound seems to mean “One whose roguery was manifest in his skill in bringing about deceits of an impossible kind and who broke a hard stone column.” Perhaps. there is a covert allusion in the word ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ïto the late King.

** P. 143. L. 19.**‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§É"Hire,‚Äù ‚Äúrecompense” [Wilson].

** P. 143. L. 20.**‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ÉGiven by the Goddess.

** P. 144. L. 3.**‡§Ö‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡§Éwho found or detected no weak point.
[47 D. k. ]

** P. 144. L. 4.** ‡§®‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§•‡§®‡•à‡§É Methods of testing a man who pretends to have divine knowledge. “He should be able to say what you have lost,what you are holding in your clenched hand (or whether the beans or the like you have there are of even or uneven number), and what you are thinking of.‚Äù [Peterson]

** P. 144. L. 6.**‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç Shaven. Formed under the V√¢rtika, ‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡•§

‡§â‡§™‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø Having caused the ‡§â‡§™‡§®‡§Ø‡§® or thread ceremony being performed.

** P. 144. L. 8.** ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç Dependent upon the three ≈öaktis, viz., (1) ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É, (2) ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Éand (3) ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Énamed in the next line ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡§Ωupported by each other.

** P. 144. L. 10.** ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§É‡•§ (1) ‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É(2) ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É(3- 4) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É‡•§ (5) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É’‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡§É‡•§ (XII 36) ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§É‡•§‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É‡•§

** P. 144. L. 11.**‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§µ‡§ø‡§ü‡§™‡§É‡•§ ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•ã ‡§Ø ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ü‡§™‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§É‡•§ ‡§∑‡§°‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§É‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡§≤‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§É‡•§ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§´‡§≤‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•§ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§´‡§≤‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§∑‡§°‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§É ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§®‡§Ø ‡§è‡§µ ‡§µ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§É‡•§ Pa·∏ç. Wilson explains the terms as under:‚Äî‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó or five parts as “friends, expedients, distinction of place and time, counteraction of evil, success.‚Äù

‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™Abundance of wealth and abundance of population.

‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§πExertion of mind, speech, body and action,

‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ÉHaving for its leaves the seventy-two Prak·πõitis. ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ (‡•ß) ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§É (‡•®) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§ó‡•Ä‡§∑‡•Å‡§É (‡•©) ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§®‡§É(‡•™) ‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§É ‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡§É‡•§ (‡•ß) ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç (‡•®) ‡§Ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç (‡•©) ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç (‡•™) ‡§Ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ó‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§ó‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‡•§ (‡•ß) ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§É (‡•®) ‡§Ü‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§É (‡•©) ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§É(‡•™) ‡§Ü‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§É‡•§ ‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§ó‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ó‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•å ‡§ö ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ (‡•ß) ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É (‡•®) ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç (‡•©) ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç (‡•™) ‡§ï‡•ã‡§∑‡§É (‡•´) ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§É ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡•à‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§ï‡•ã‡§∑‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§É(‡•ß‡•®*‡•´=‡•¨‡•¶) ‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡§∏‡•É‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§π (‡•¨‡•¶+‡•™+‡•Æ) ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§™‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§ T√¢r√¢kum√¢ra Kaviratna. Key to Cal Univ. Course 1889 ‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§ø‡§É Kautiliya VI. 2-97. ‡§Æ‡•å‡§≤‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂ ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç K√°mandaka XII. 25.

‡§∑‡§°‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡§≤‡§Ø‡§ÉHaving for its tender sprouts the six expedients, viz. ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§ÉAmara II. 8. 19.

‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§´‡§ÉHaving might (‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø) and success (‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø) as flower and fruit, respectively.

** P. 144. L. 12.** ‡§®‡§Ø‡§µ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É the tree of politics. Cf. ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç M√¢lavik√¢gnimitra Act I. Also ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§ú‡§≤‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ù‡§∞‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§≤‡§∂‡•à‡§É ‡•§ ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§§‡§æ Mudr√¢r√¢kshasa Act V. (Chh√¢y√¢). Cf. also ‡§Ö‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∑‡§ü‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç K√¢mandaka VIII. 42.

‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç on account of its complexity.

** P. 144. L. 15.** ‡§™‡•á‡§∂‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç Pa·∏ç.

** P. 144. L. 16.**‡§∞‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•çInstructed or directed in private. The instruction conveyed in the next three lines to N√¢l√Æja·πÖgha closely follows the precepts laid down in the ‡§ï‡•å‡§ü‡§ø‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Øin Prakara·πáa VI under the head of ‡§â‡§™‡§ß‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•å‡§ö‡§æ‡§∂‡•å‡§ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç. This can alone explain the significance of the epithets of ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑ and ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó applied to himself by ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§in lines 15 and 16. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑deceitful person.

** P. 144. L. 17.** ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó a serpent, a dissolute person.

** P. 144. L. 18.** ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§ and ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§ have for subject ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§Éin L. 16.

** P. 144. L. 19.**‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•à‡§ÉPa·∏ç.

** P. 144. L. 20.** ‡§Ö‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç An opportunity being found in extreme confidence.

‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§™‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§®According to the policy unfolded by you. ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç Judgment or discernment.

** P. 144. L. 22**. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§¨‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç Valour.

** P. 14. L. 23.** ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§£‡§Æ‡•çValiant towards or in meeting one’s enemies.

** P. 145. L. 1.** ‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§¨‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§Æ‡§É‡•§ The Karanja (Butea frondosa) tree the juice ofwhich has a nasty and repellent smell. Hence ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§is repellent to enemies but fragrant like Sandal to those who are submissive to him.

** P. 145. L. 3.** ‡§â‡§™‡§ß‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø Having tested him by many wily tricks. Vide Note on L. 15. P. 144.

** P. 145.L. 4**. ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•çmy counsellor.

‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç variously disguised ‡§ó‡•Ç‡§¢‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç Pa·∏ç. ‡§≤‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡§Æ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ç avaricious or covetous and prosperous. ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç Arrogant.

** P. 145. L. 6.**‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•çAlmost disobedient or refractory. ‡§Ö‡§≤‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç Proclaiming my disinterestedness. ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç Promoting or encouraging piety.

** P. 145. L. 7.** ‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§ß‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç Getting rid of thorns i. e., those likely to give trouble. ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§ò‡§®‡•çCounter. acting the wiles of enemies.

** P. 145. L. 8.** ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç My collect revenue.

‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§ÉThe course of conduct laid down in political science has its root in wealth or is dependent upon the possession of material resources Cf. ‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•á‡§§‡§ø K√°mandaka XIV. 33.

** P. 145. L. 9.** ‡§® ‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§Ç Cf. ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç M·πõichchhaka·π≠ikaAct I. 37.

‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•çOn account of weakness in that, i. e., inriches.

‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó here must be understood in the restricted sense which it bears in political science viz., means of acquisition of wealth.

THE END.

Index to proper names in the P√ªrvap√Æ»õhik√¢.

‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§ü‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ
‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£

‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§Ø‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø
‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§ö‡•Ä‡§™‡§§‡§ø
‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§§‡§π‡§≤‡§ø
‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï
‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∂‡§∂‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï
‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§∂‡§∂‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡§æ
‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§¨‡§ø
‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó
‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞
‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§∂‡•á‡§ñ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï
‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§∏‡•á‡§® ‡§∂‡•å‡§®‡§ï
‡§µ‡•á‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä
‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§ó‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ
